div.head: Prologue.
div.l: VEry unfortunate this Play has bin;
A slippery trick was play'd as by Scapin.
Whilst here our Actors made along delay,
When some were idle, others ran away,
The City House comes out with half our Play.
We fear, that having heard of this so long,
Your expectation now will do it wrong.
The Poet does a dang'rous trial make,
And all the common Roads of Plays forsake.
Vpon the Actors it depends too much,
And who can hope ever to see two such
As the Fam'd Harlequin & Scaramouch.
This well he knew.—
Yet rather chose in new attempts to fail,
Than in the old indifferently prevail.
Great Wits refrain this writing, 'cause 'tis low,
They oftner write to please themselves than you.
Like but the Play, let others have the name,
Let both French and Italians share the fame,
But if't be bad, let them too bear the blame.

Octavio, Son to Scaramouch. Mr. Clark.
Cynthio, Son to Pancrace. Mr. Wiltshire.
Spitzaferro, a Coward ignorant and bold. Mr. Cartwright.

div.head: SCARAMOUCH.
ACT I. SCENE I. A Brick-house.

sp.speaker: Octavio.
sp.p: AH too Cruel News for a Poor Lover; the Person I adore must this day by the Commands of her Parents resign her self to the imbraces of one she loaths and hates: this Letter she sent to me for Releif— What's to be done?

div.stage: Enter a Fencing, a Dancing, and Singing Master.
All three, Good Morrow, good Morrow Signior,

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I have earnest business calls me abroad this morning, I cannot stay to learn my Exercises now, but let me see you at this Hour to morrow: your Servant gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Omnes▪
sp.p: Ha Harlequin.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior Dancero.
sp.stage: Sings and dances and makes legs.
sp.p: Signior Singero.
sp.stage: Sings out and then singsa piece of a Tune.
sp.p: Signior Fencero, Euh.
sp.stage: Makes Thrusts at him As if he were fencing.
sp.p: Euh, Euh, Servitore, Servitore.

sp.speaker: Fenc.
sp.p: Good morrow, good morrow to you.

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: You are very Merry.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p:
You have been teaching Signior Octavio his exercises.
Signior Chantero i'le sing you a rejoycing Air, pourpassa— tempio una Alegare●zza, una Ca●sona, Bella, Bella,

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: O Rarely well sung Signior Harlequin.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Singing and Dancing I understand well enough. But Signior Alonge, I don't Comprehend the Mistery of your Vocation, what need is there of killing a Man by Rule?

sp.speaker: Fence.
sp.p: The art of Fencing consists in two things, to give and not to receive that is, to ofsend, and defend.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: That is to run a Man through, and not be run through, which is to kill and not be killed, ha-

sp.speaker: Fenc.
sp.p: Right, and 'tis impossible you shou'd receive, if you know how to turn the Sword of your Enemy from the line of your Body. And this depends only on the Motion of the wrist, As—— in thus, and out— thus.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: A man then whether he be valiant or not, If he has but this art, is sure to kill a Man and not be hanged for it.

sp.speaker: Fenc.
sp.p: And not be killed.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: O not be kill'd, but if he be hang'd 'tis as bad.

sp.speaker: Fenc.
sp.p: This which I tell you is demonstration.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Oh, Oh, but I can give you better demonstration, how a man may not be kill'd▪

sp.speaker: Fenc.
sp.p: As how?

div.stage: Herl. Fences and Iumps forwards and backward with his Wooden Sword against the Fencer, His foil, and at last runs away.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: For example There—

sp.speaker: Fenc.
sp.p: There is no guard indeed like a good pair of Heels, But if you run away how will you do to kill your Enemies?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Come behind him and Shoot him, or kill him pissing against a Wall, Demonstration, a sure way to kill and not be kill'd,

sp.speaker: Fenc.
sp.p: But a Gentleman ought to have Honour and Gallantry.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: I was not born a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Fenc.
sp.p: There's nothing so commendable as the knowledg of Arms. This Imports more than all other Sciences. Singing and dancing are things unprofitable in respect of this.

sp.speaker: Dance.
sp.p: Very good, my Master of Defence, pray don't so much undervalue dancing.

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: Nor speak so slightly of Musick.

sp.speaker: Fence.
sp.p: You won't I hope compare Hopping and Squealing to the Noble Science of Defence?

sp.speaker: Dance.
sp.p: There's a Man of Confidence.

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: A very pleasant Fellow.

sp.speaker: Fence.
sp.p: Why my Nimble Sir, such another word, and I shall lead you a new dance, and make you my little Canary Bird change your Note.

sp.speaker: Danc.
sp.p: If you are at that good Mr. Fencer, I shall teach you your business a little better.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Eh, are you mad to quarrel with a Man that understands to Fight in Teirce and in Quart? and knows how to kill a Man by Demonstration?

sp.speaker: Danc.
sp.p: I care not for his demonstration, for his Tierce▪ nor his Quart.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Eh, Eh.

sp.speaker: Fenc.
sp.p: How you Grasshopper, you Skip Jack, you Hop-myThum.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Eh, Mr. of Defence.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: You cold Iron Carrier, you spit-frog, you Scarecrow, Bravo.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Eh, Mr. Dancer.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.p: If once I fall upon your bones—

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Eh, No.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: And if I take you to task—

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Eh Fye.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.p: I'l make you dance to a new Tune.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Eh, Pray.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: And I'l learn you to mind your hits.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Eh, Fie No!

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: Stand aside, we'l give him Demonstration.

sp.speaker: Herl.
sp.p: Eh, No, No, Pray, Auh!
Hola, Signior Scaramouch, you come very luckyly With your Learning and Wisdom to perswade 'em to Peace and quietness.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: They are quarrelling about their Professions, and going to fight it out, Which is best?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Wherefore are you thus transported with rage? Have you not learn't Moral Philosophy? which teacheth the Government of our Passions. Have you never read the Learned Treatise Seneca compos'd of Choller. Ought not reason to be Masters of our Passions?

sp.speaker: Danc.
sp.p: But Signior Scaramouch, he had the impudence t'affront us, and speak contemptously of our Professions, and undervalue singing and dancing.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: A wise man is above injuries, and the best return to affronts is Moderation and Patience.

sp.speaker: Fence.
sp.p: They had both of 'em the Impudence to compare their two Professions of singing and dancing to the Noble Science of defence.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: And ought you to be concern'd at this? is this sufficient to cause such irregular emotions, it is vain Glory to make comparisons, Wisdom and Virtue only give distinction.

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: There is nothing so profitable to the Publique as Musick.

sp.speaker: Danc.
sp.p: Nor nothing so necessary to Mankind as dancing

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: All the disorders, all the Wars which have been in the World have happen'd, for not having learn'd Musick.

sp.speaker: Danc.
sp.p: All the misfortunes of Mankind, all the lamentable Stories which we read of in History, the disapointments of Councils, the failuers of great Generals, and defeats of Armies have bin thro' want of Dancing.

sp.speaker: Fenc.
sp.p: Ha, Ha, Ha.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: Does not War proceed from the want of Union among men?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: And if all men wou'd learn Musick, wou'd not they accord better with one another? And wou'd not there be an universal peace and quietness in the World? Peace is when all men agree in a Harmonious Concurrence, Peace and Concord are the same thing.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Oh!—

sp.speaker: Danc.
sp.p: When a man fails in his conduct, whether it be in respect to the affairs of his— Family, or the Government of the Kingdom, or in the Command of an Army, is it not always said of such a man he did not go well about his business; he did not take the right time? And so,—

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Oh!—▪

sp.speaker: Danc.
sp.p: And how shou'd a man go well, or do any thing in time, that can't Dance?

sp.speaker: Fenc.
sp.p: Ha, Ha, Ha.

sp.speaker: Danc.
sp.p: Here now you see the profitableness of Dancing, and Musick, Dancing is therefore a Science absolutely necessary to mankind.

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: And Musick is a Science without which the World cannot subsist.

sp.speaker: Fenc.
sp.p: And how will you Govern without the Sword? And where are your Generals and Armies without men that understand their Weapons? Therefore I maintain against them both, that the Science of Desence is the noblest and most necessary of all Sciences whatever.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: And what think you all of Philosophy? You are all three very impertinent to give the name of Science to your professions. A Fencer, a Musician, A Dancer. A Hector, a Fidler, and a Jack Pudding.

sp.speaker: Fenc.
sp.p: Out you lowsie Philosopher.

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: You Pittiful Pedant.

sp.speaker: Danc.
sp.p: You formal Blockhead.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: How you Rascals?

div.stage: He falls on them with his sists, and they buffet him.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Eh, Signior Philosopher.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Slaves, Rogues, Rascals.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior Philosopher.

sp.speaker: Fenc.
sp.p: Dunce, Blockhead.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Gentlemen!

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Impudent Rogues.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior Philosopher.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Ignorant Sots▪

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior Philosopher, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Rascals.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior Phisosopher.

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: Impertinent Philosopher.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Curs, Dogs, Sots, Rogues, Rascals, Villains.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior Philosopher, Gentlemen.
Signior Philosopher, Gentlemen, Signior Philosopher; e'ne fight Dog, sight Bear, and the Devil part 'em, l've done all I can.

div.stage: Re-enter Scaramouch composing himself, and Harlequin Counterfeiting a Rage.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Ha! Impertinent Rogues, Rascals, Ignorant Sots, Illiterate Beasts, Curs, Dogs, Whelps, Knaves. Villains.—

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Moderate this Passion, anger is offensive to the Eyes of a Philosopher.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: No body must be angry but himself, Rogues, Affront a learned Philosopher!

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: It imports not, a Philosopher can bear injuries as he ought, I will go write a Book against Musick, dancing, and Fencing, and undo all the Professors of it by Argument.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: That I was but a Philosopher to have this Command and Government over my Passions.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: O my cross fortunes, O my Aurelia, I'le call her forth, to know if she at last resolves by her obedience to make me wretched, and her self unhappy— St— St— Signiora Aurelia.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Who's there, Signior Octavio?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Ah Aurelia, is that true, which this Letter Imports? are you to be marri'd so soon?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Such is the appointment of my Father.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: What has occasion'd this sudden Resolution?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: He finds his Sickness to increase, and the Phisicians grow doubtful of his Recovery, wherefore he has presixt the time of my Marriage, that he may see me well dispos'd of as he thinks, before he dyes—▪ but what Change is this I see in you? Why in your Countenance do you wear these marks of Sorrow? Do you doubt my Fidelity? Or are you not assur'd of the love I have for you?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Yes Aurelia, I am assur'd you love me, but have no Assurance you will ever love me. I have heard say, that the love of your Sex is not so lasting as that of ours, and that passions in Womens brests are like Flames rising from light perishable Substance, which decay even as soon as they are born.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: My Heart then is not like those of other Women, I perceive well enough, that the Fervency of my love cannot be abated but by death.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: I believe that you really think what you speak. But I dread a power that in your heart will combat against those tender Sentiments it has sor me, your Dependance is on a Fathers will, that already is determin'd to dispose of you.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: No Octavio, 'tis not in a Fathers Power to force me to break my Vows to you, I'm resolv'd to abandon my Family, nay my Life, rather then quit you.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: O blest Assurance!

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: After this you are no longer to doubt me, but indeavour my Relief, if it shou'd come to the extremity, think therefore how to dispose of me, if I am forc'd to fly from this Marriage?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: I will instantly go and advise with some faithful Friend.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Heaven will be favourable to our Vows.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Heaven cannot be cross to me, if you are constant.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Most assuredly I will, Adieu.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: I shall then be happy.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: My Father arriv'd?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior Si.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: And this morning?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: This morning.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: And return'd say'st thou with a Resolution to have me marry?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior Si.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: The Daughter of Signior Scaramouch?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Of Signior Scaramouch.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: And that Signior Octavio is to marry my Sister, and make it a cross match?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: A cross match.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: Cross indeed to us both. My Fathers Voyage then to Lauretto, was not out of Devotion as he pretended, but to fetch them from the Monastry.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: From the Monastry.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: And you met my Father just as he came ashore?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior Si.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: And he told you this?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior Si.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: And he knows all my concerns thou say'st?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: All.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: And that in his absence I have made a contract?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: A Contract.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: Prithee speak to me, and don't in this manner catch my last words.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: you forget not the least circumstance.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: How's that Signior Cynthio, your Father arriv'd, and knows you are Contracted?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior si.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: O Octavio! Counsel me what's to be done in this juncture?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: I'm at as great a plunge, and want a Counsellor my self.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: As soon as my Father see's me, a Tempest of outrage will pour upon me— his Reproaches will be most violent.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Methinks I already see his Brow bent with fury against you, and his Cane lifted above his head, to give you a thousand dry drubs for the folly you have committed.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: How shall I avoid the storm?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: How shall I secure my Love?

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Who's here! Signior Octavio? Signior Cynthio, how is't, what's the matter? why look you both so melancholy?

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: Signior Plautino I'm undone.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: And I the most unfortunate man in the World.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: How? In what?

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: My Father is arrived with a resolution to have me marry.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: And Aurelia to morrow is to be married to Spittzaferro.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: And what harm is there in all this to you two?

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: You know not our concerns.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: No, but 'tis in your power to tell me, and I am a man of great Consolation, one that Negotiates in the affairs of young Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: O Plautino, if you could find any invention to draw me out of this trouble that I am just falling into, I should think I ow'd even my life to you.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: And if you cou'd prevent or but delay this Marriage—

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: To tell you the truth, nothing almost is impossible to me, Heaven has blest me with a genious fit for all manner of witty Contrivances, and pretty Inventions, therefore tell me your grievances.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: You know 'tis a month since my Father took a Voyage to Lawretto.—

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: I know it Sir.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: A few days after his departure, Signior Octavio and I in our rambles, met with a Troop of them that call themselves Egyptians.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Fortune-tellers.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior Si, Gypsies.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: They had in their company a young Girl, of beautiful Features, that Sung and Danced to a Miracle, who had in all she did such acharming Air.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: That you cou'd not chuse but fall in love.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior Si, at the same time she stole Signior Cynthio's heart and my money.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: I know not if it were the agreeableness of these good qualities of Singing and Dancing—

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: and picking of Pockets.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: First raised in me an unconquerable Passion.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: So.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: After two or three Visits, the Company wou'd Permit me to make no addresses to her without a Contract of Marriage, which after much strugling with my Passion, I consented to.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: You are then Contracted to her?

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: Yes, and have not the least regret for what I have done, but languish for the happy hour to consummate the Marriage.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: What stop?

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: Before I take her from them I am to lay down two hundred Pistols for the expence of her Education, and to recompence the loss the whole Company will suffer by her departure.

sp.speaker: Plaul.
sp.p: I understand▪ Deposit the sum.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: 'Tis that I want.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Borrow't.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: I forged a plausible story to a Friend of my Fathers, that I wanted so much for his use in his absence, who had promised it me within two days; But now my Father's arrived, that design's ruin'd, and I am too cruelly disappointed.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: And this is your grievance?

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: It is.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Now Signior Octavio, let me know your resentments.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: I have long bin in love with the fair Aurelia whose passion corresponds with mine, but her Father is averse to it, and proposes Signior Spittzaferro for her Husband, and he's too wealthy a Rival to be Supplanted.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: But are you sure Aurelia loves you?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Yes, and hates Spitzaferro.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Then fear nothing.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Yes I have much to fear. To secure her mind I drew her to a Contract.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Better and better.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Her Father who has long languished under a great fit of sickness, apprehending his death is near, with all speed presses her Marriage, and has appointed that to morrow shall make her a Bride to my Rival.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: It cannot be, it must not, it sha'not.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: These are words of comfort.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: And all that troubles you is your want of money to purchase your dear, pretty little Creature, and the fear you have to see your father, after his having heard of your engagement.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: And my care is for Money to provide for the Person I love, if being Pres't to this Marriage she be forced to sly from her Fathers importunity and Anger.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Good Heavens, that you should call me to counsel for this, had you not one pritty invention, one little Stratagem, where's thy wit Harlequin, are thy Brains Addle?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: O Signior Plautino, I am better at Execution then Invention.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Well, we'l try what performance you have.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: Do you believe—

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Euh no more, but think how to receive your fathers onset, without being daunted.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: I tremble to think of his coming, and have a natural timerousness in me, that I can't ore come, were't any but a Father—

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: You must in the first encounter show your self a man, least finding you give ground, he proceeds to treat you like a Child; go and practice how to behave your self; take courage and Resolution; be possitive in all your answers and obstinate.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: I'l endeavour.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Accustom your self a little by Practice, come let's see how you'l behave your self. Your Posture bold, your head upright, your looks assured.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: So.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Good, now imagine I am your Father arriv'd, and answer me as you would do him, Hau! Villain, disobedient Villain, ungratious Varlet, the greif of thy Parents, and shame to thy Family, the dishonour and burden of my old Age, unworthy as thou art to bear the name of my Son; how dare you appear before me, that have in my absence, given me so much cause of displeasure, and done as thou hast done? Is this the reward of my care to give thee breeding? Is this the best return you make me, this the respect due to a Father? Is this your duty and obedience? Go ungratious wretch as thou art, hadst thou the boldness, the impudence, to engage your self without my consent and approbation, to marry without my leave or knowledg, answer me, answer me, you that sneak so, what have you to say for your self? What are you struck dumb?

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: I cant but imagine 'tis my Father himself that rants thus at me.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: He swaggers like one of threescore, cuds-so h'has made me tremble.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: You must not therefore behave your self like a Boy that is affraid of a Rod; come he's not your Schoolmaster, but your Father.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: I'l go in and fortify my self with resolutions, I'm resolv'd not to be danted.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Not so much as in looks.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Nor hang you head.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Nor be not Mealy Mouth'd.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: No, I'l give him two words for one.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Cudso, an excellent Tutor and an apt Scholler.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Don't bate him an Ace.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: Not a tittle, you have whetted me, and I am sharp.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: See your Father is coming.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Signior Octavio retire, and leave us the Field to our selves.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior Si, let us stand aside, and see the Battle, whiz the Bullets will fly Anon.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: O my heart failes me.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: No, no, stay you, Sir stay.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Euh, Eo poura, Signior, Eo poura.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Come bear up.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: I can't stand the Brunt, I'l e'ne get out of his sight

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Signior Cynthio, stay Signior Cynthio, see He's gon, what ill temper'd mettle is this Blade made of? That his edg is turn'd already; well I'l speak to him, do you second me, and be sure to back my discourse.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Was ever the like Action in a Son?

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: He has heard the business already, and can't forbear talking on't to himself.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: so villainous a peice of Insolence.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Let's harken a little nearer.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: I'd fain know what he can say for himself.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: We have our Story ready.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Does he think to deny his Marriage?

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: No, that's the least of our thoughts.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Or hopes he to excuse it?

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: As well as we can.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Or will he tell me some fine Story?

sp.speaker: Plant.
sp.p: It may be we may.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: It shall be to no purpose.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: We'l try that.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: I'l harken to nothing.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Reason or not Reason.

sp.speaker: Penc.
sp.p: I'l lay him up in Lavender.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: His fears make him require sweeting. Sir I am glad to see you safe return'd.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Good morrow Plautino, I'l go find him out.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: I believe Sir your voyage agreed with you very well, you are grown fat upon it, and look mighty well.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: I am very well,— marry without my knowledg?

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Had you not a very pleasent Voyage?

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: A very pleasant one, pray let me alone to be angry.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: How Sir, wou'd you be angry?

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Yes Sir, I have reason to be angry I think.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: With whom?

sp.speaker: Pance.
sp.p: With my Son.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: For what I beseech you?

sp.speaker: Penc.
sp.p: You have not heard what has been done in my absense.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: I heard of some small matter.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: How! an action of this nature, a small matter?

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: 'Tis true you have some reason to.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Twas such a Prank.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Yes truly but—

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: A Son to marry without the consent of his Father.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Something may be said as to that indeed, but I know you are a man of that Wisdom not to be too much concern'd at what cann't be help't.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Not to be concern'd, yes I will be concern'd, don't you think, that I have all reason immaginable to be angry?

sp.speaker: Plant.
sp.p: Yes truly you have so, I was angry my self when I first heard on't, I was so much concern'd for your sake, that I school'd your Son soundly, ask him there what a Lecture I read him for his want of respect to a Father, to whose least commands he ought to show obedience, no man cou'd have said more, not your self. But I have since considered things according to Reason, and find (now my Passion is gone) that they are not so bad as may be imagin'd,

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: How? What can be worse, then for a Son to run headlong, and Marry no body knows who?

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Oh, I grant it was not well done, but what? our Actions depend not altogether on us, the Stars have a powerful influence. In sine, it was his Fate.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: That's a fine Reason indeed, by that means a man may Cheat, Rob, Murder, and say for excuse, 'Twas his Fate so to do.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: But Sir, you take my words in too strict a Philosophical a sense, yet Fate is hard to be resisted, and the influence of the Stars, concur much to the Operations of our Minds.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: But does not wisdom controul the Stars, and the Fate you: talk of? Sapiens Dominabitur Astris—

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: 'Tis true, Wisdom corrects but cannot quite alter the course of the Stars— But what, you don't expect to see your Son at these years as wise as your self?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: As for example, young Mr. Octavio, notwithstanding all my good Counsels, daily Advice, Remonstrances, Cautions and Caveats, has yet play'd a more foolish trick then Signior Cynthio.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: I wou'd fain know if you were not young once your self, and had not your Devices and Vigaries like others? I have heard say that you were heretofore very brisk upon the Ladies, a great Gallant, and kept Company with all the Ladies of the times.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: 'Tis confest, but I had still a regard to my self, I never did what he has done.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: And what has he done? He saw a young Lady whom he loved, he had that from you to have a kindness for all pretty Women. He found her very charming, made her visits, look'd languishingly on her, sigh'd and talk'd passionately, and declared his love in all the gallantries of Courtship. She makes a return, he is weak, the temptation strong, his Stars conspire, Fate helps, Opportunity presents, he makes use of the Critical minute, the Parents surprise him, force him to marry her, he gives her his Hand, and makes the best of a bad Market, and yet you'l be angry.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Ha, Ha, Ha, Rogue!

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: What wou'd you have had him been kill'd? it is yet better to be Marry'd then Murther'd.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: I ne're heard that matters went so far.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Ask him, see if he don't say the same thing?

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Was he forc'd to marry?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Oh Signior si, with a great Battoon.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Nay I'de not lye for the matter.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Then he shall presently go to a Notary, and Depose upon Oath, that he was forc't to't.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: But that's a thing he'l never do.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: I'le have it done to annul the Marriage.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: To annual the Marriage?

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Ah, you won't annul it Signior Pancrace.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Won't I annul it?

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Why have not I the Authority of a Father? Is it not Reason and Justice for the violence offer'd my Son—

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: He will never agree to't.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Not agree to't?

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Not my Son?

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: No, not your Son, wou'd you have him declare himself a Coward? and say that he did it for fear? Oh, he never will, that were to disgrace himself and his Family, and make him unworthy to be the Son of such a Father as you?

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: I care not for that.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: He must for his own reputation and your honour, say that his Marriage was his own choice.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: But I'le have him for my Honour and his own Reputation, say just the contrary.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: I'me sure he never will.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: I'le make him.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Indeed he will not▪

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: He shall, or I'le disinherit him.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: You?

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: I.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Good!

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: I'le do't.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: No, you'l not disinherit him.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Won't I disinherit him?

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: But I will.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: No?

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: That's fine, I won't disinherit my Son!

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Signior, No.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Who shall hinder me?

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Your self.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: My self, good!

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Yes, you can't have the heart.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: But you'l find I shall.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Nature and the compassion of a Father will take his part.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: They'l signifie nothing.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Yes, Yes.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: I know you are naturally of a good disposition.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: No, I am not, I can be angry if I please, but let's end this discourse which provokes me. I'le go and find out Signior Scaramouch, and acquaint him with the fine Actions of my Son.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Signior Pancrace, if I can be serviceable to you in any thing, you need but Command.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: I thank you Signior Plautino, O that I had but my Son alive that is dead, to make him my Heir.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: You are an able man, our business is now in a good Posture, but Money, Money, Signior Plautino, Eh, 'tis a Pritty Gipsie.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: I engage— The design is hatch'd, I am only thinking where to find a man that we may trust to act a part that I have designed stay, stand you at a little distance, give your Hat, the Cock of an angry Bully, sway your body upon one leg, set one hand by your side, swell, look fierce and killing, now take an angry march round, now turn short Cock before and behind at once, now quickly draw, ha, advance with a countenance full of fury, as if you had found the man you were to sacrifice. So— 'tis well, I shall put fit words into your mouth, and instruct you to disguise your visage, and alter your voice.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Eh, Signior Plautino, don't put me to swim out of my depth, I have no good heart for a Lyon.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: O a Lamb in a Lions skin is as dreadful to the eye as a Lions whelp.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: And lot the fear of the Galleys be before your eyes.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: We'l share the danger betwixt us, three years more or less in the Galleys is not sufficient to restrain a noble heart from a brave understanding.

div.trailer: The End of the first Act.

div.head: Act. II. Scene I.

sp.speaker: SPitt.
sp.p: Ah Signior Plautino, I meet you very luckily, I was just coming to find you.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: For what Signior Spittzaferro?

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: To ask your advice about a business I have in hand.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: I'm very glad I meet you, here we may discourse with freedom.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Be cover'd I beseech you, 'tis concerning a matter of great importance, but it is not good to proceed in matters of this nature without the counsel and advice of Friends.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: I take it as a particular honour, Signior Spittzaferro, that you make choice of me. Well Sir, acquaint me with the business.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: But first I desire you not to flatter me, but really and truly to tell me your thoughts.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Well, since you desire it, I will.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: There's nothing I should sooner find fault with, than a friend that won't freely tell me his mind.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: You are in the right.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: In this Age 'tis very hard to find a sincere friend.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Very true.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Wherefore Signior Plautino give me your advice, with all the freedom imaginable.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: There's my Hand upon't.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Swear to me.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: By our friendship, as I hope to live. Now tell me what ist?

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: I wou'd know whether you think it convenient for me to marry or not?

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: For you to marry?

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Yes, I my self in Person, what wou'd you counsel me?

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: I tell you plainly, that 'twill be very indiscreetly done of you to marry, for marriage is a thing that even young people ought to consider of before they do it, and if marriage at the best be counted the greatest of follies, what can be worse than to be guilty of this folly, at an Age when we shou'd be more discreet. In short Sir, I tell you my opinion, I wou'd not counsel you to marry, and you'l be thought the indiscreetest man in the world, having liv'd free to these years, if you shou'd now thrust your neck into the yoak.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: And I tell you Signior Plautino, that I'm resolv'd to marry, come what will, and that no body will count me a fool for marrying the Gentlewoman I pretend to, when once they see what manner of person she is.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: O! that alters the Case, you did not tell me that.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: She's one that's very pritty, and one that I love very well.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: You love her very well?

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: With all my heart, and I have her Fathers consent.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Oh, you have her Fathers consent too?

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Yes, and I have promis'd to be marri'd to morrow.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: O Marry, Marry, I have no more to say.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: I was formerly against marrying, but now I consider if I continue as I am, the race of the Spittzaferro's will be at an end, and in marrying I shall live after I am dead, in my issue.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Therefore you'l do very well to marry.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Yes, what a pleasure I shall take to see a Company of little Creatures, to whom I gave life and motion, and are so many small Figures of my self, there shall I see my self drawn to the life in little. O how these little images will be hopping and jumping about me, and calling me Pa pa, talking and prattling, and telling me a company of pritty little foolish tales, O the dear pritty little Poppets, what can be more delightful.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Nothing in the world, therefore marry the first thing you do.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Very good, you give me that Counsel.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: I counsel you, you can't do better.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Truly I am very well pleased to find you counsel me so like a friend.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: But who is this Person you are to marry?

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: One Mistress Aurelia.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: What the pritty young Mistriss Aurelia?

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: She that is so modish and waggish?

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Daughter to Signior Ieronimo?

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: The same.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: And Sister to young Alberto that has a command in the Castle?

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: 'Tis she, but him I never saw yet, he's in the Country.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Mercy upon me?

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: What say you Signior?

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: A very fit person for you, marry with all speed.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Have I not made a good choice?

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: A rare one, ah, what a fine Wife will you have, Marry, Marry, Marry Signior Spittzaferro.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Your approbation pleases me extreamly, I give you many thanks for your good counsel, and invite you to my Wedding to morrow.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: I'le not fail to come. The young Aurelia Daughter to Signior Ieronimo, marry'd to Signior Spittzaferro, that is not above 53 years of Age; oh what a match, what a fine match is this?

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: This match must needs be very happy, for every body is much pleas'd that hears on't, I have not told it to one but smil'd at my choice as soon as I speak, I shall to morrow be the happiest man in the world. O here comes my Mistress.

Ah! how pritty, what an Air, how delicately shap'd, and what a Stature! Can any man see her and not have a mind to her? whether art thou going my little Poppet, my dear Wife that is to be, of thy Husband that must be?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I'm going about a little business.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p:
Euh— good, my little Mopsie, the hour is coming that we two must make one another happy, I can do with you what e're I please, without any Body's saying why do you so? or is it well done? you will be mine all over from head to foot, I shall then be your right owner, and Master of you all over, of your pritty waggish Eyes, of that pretty little Roguish Nose, of those Cherry-Cherry lips, of those little, little, fritter Ears, of those
pretty blub-cheeks,— of that dimpl'd, dimpl'd Chin, of those round, hard, panting Bubbies, of your soft, white Skin, of your— Euh— oh!— In fine, every part and particle of you will be solely and wholly at my disposal; and I shall be the like to you, to be stroak'd and kiss'd, and do what e're you please with, Are you not glad of this Marriage, my little Wanton?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Most extremely glad, I'll assure you: For to say truth, my Father's severity has kept me in a most intollerable subjection, I have been almost mad for a little more liberty, and especially e're since he was sick. He has kept me so mew'd up in his warm Chamber, that I have wanted room to breath in. Were it not for you, that I must go abroad to buy things for our Wedding, I shou'd never have stirr'd from him: Ah! the fresh Air is so comfortable to me.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: — And the sight of me,—

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Above all,— I have wish'd a thousand times that he would marry me to somebody, that I might get out of his Jurisdiction, and be a little more at my own disposal; and you, I thank you, are come most luckily to do me that good turn.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: I'll take you into my tuition.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Aye— Signior Spittzaferro, and now I'l be preparing to lead a pleasanter life, to take my full swing of pleasure, to make amends for what I have lost.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Eumh!

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Now, Sir, you being a very brave person, well bred and one that understands what it is to live, I believe that we shall do well together; and that you will not be one of those troublesome Husbands that wou'd have their Wives live sneaking and mew'd up; 'tis a thing that does not at all agree with me, I shou'd never away with't in a Husband; I can't endure a dull solitary life, 'tis directly against my humour; I'm all Air and Mirth; I like to go where I please, and do what I list.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Eumh!

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I love Visiting. Plays, Balls, Masquerades, and good Company: I'm for good Clothes,— a sine Coach, and handsome Liveries, and appearing amongst the best, as well drest, and as rich as any of e'm.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Eumh! yes, yes.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: In fine, I'm resolv'd to make my life as pleasant as I can; and I know you'l think your self happy to have a Wife of my humour.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Eumh;— Yes, yes.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: We'l never be medling, nor thwarting one another; I'l not concern my self at what you do: As I hope, on the other side, you'l not be contradicting, or telling me what I shall do.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Eumh; no, no.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: As for my part, I think there ought to be a mutual compliance, and that people ought not to marry to be troublesome to one another. In fine, when we are married we'l live like two that understand one anothers humour; no jealousy nor suspitious shall trouble your head, but it shall be sufficient that you have an assurance of my fidelity; as I shall have a good opinion of yours. But what troubles you, I perceive your countenance much chang'd on the sudden?

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Some splenatick vapours that rise and dizzy my brain.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: 'Tis a distemper that abundance are troubled with. But our Marriage will take away all that. Adieu, Signior Spittzaferro, my dear Husband,— That must be, of your Wife that is to be. I am in a little hast at present, because I have not Clothes and things about me as I wou'd have; I'm just going to buy me what things I want, you shall see how sine I'l be to morrow— Adieu Signior Spittzaferro.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Signior Spittzaferro, I'm glad to find you still here: I met just now a Jeweller who had the finest Diamond-Ring that I have ever seen; and thinking you might want one to present to your Mrs. I earnestly entreated him to come to you, and let you see't. He will be here presently.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: No hast, no hast, Sir.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: How! what mean you, Signior Spittzaferro, you were very hot upon't e'en now?

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p:
Since that I have some scruples come into my head concerning my Marriage: I will very well consider on't before I proceed any farther; I wou'd sain have somebody interpret to me a Dream which I had last night; and but just now call to mind. You know that Dreams are as they were Glasses, that represent to us things that shall happen. I dreamt that I
was in a Ship, and the Sea very tempestuous; and that—

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Signior Spittzaferro, I have a little urgent business at present that will not let me stay to hear you out; I have no skill in dreams, besides, I give no credit to e'm. But as for consultation about your Marriage, hear a couple of very learn'd Philosophers, your Neighbours, Signior Scaramouch, and Signior Doctor Pancracio, one a bold Aristotelian, and the other a modest Academick; with them you may debate about every particular of your Marriage, they being of different Sects, you may hear their several opinions, and from both judg what's best for you to do; for my part, I'm satisfi'd with what I said to you before: And so your Servant.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: He's in the right; I ought in this case to consult these learned Men.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: This unadvised Marriage of my Son extremely alters the measures we had taken.—

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Strange folly of youth!

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: But no matter, Signior Scaramouch.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Let me tell you that—

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: I'l suddenly remove all obstacles.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: That the education of children—

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Is not altogether sufficient to prevent e'm from running into extravagancies, because nature is subject to frailty, and we are sometimes deceived by ill under the species of good.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Signior, no, that—

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: That it is better to bestow it upon a Son than an Estate, because Wealth respects only the body, and may be taken from us; but we cannot be depriv'd of our virtues, which are the riches of the mind, because more permanent, and of greater importance.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: No, that—

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: That it cannot be taught in old age, because the habits that are grown up with us are too deeply fix'd in nature, to be rooted out.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: No, that—

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: That unless it be given to youth, they will miscarry all their life long, because they want the Bridle that shou'd curb and restrain e'm in their full carreer.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: No, that—

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: That nothing can be more beneficial, because without it we are things unpolish'd, and rather Bruits than Men.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: No, that—

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: That, what? what, Signior Scaramouch?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Euh! Signior Doctore!

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Oh, Bono!—

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Oh, Patientia!—

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Signiorsi.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: That the education of children—

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Is a task—

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Signior, no.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Is of that consequence.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Signior, no.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Is of such a value—

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Signior, no.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Is a thing t—

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Signior, no, no, no, Signior no.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Why, what is it then, Signior Scaramouch?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: You have done?

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Signiorsi.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: You have no more to say?

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Signior, no.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: You are satisfy'd.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Signiorsi.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: You'l hear me now?

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Signiorsi.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: And not interrupt me?

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Signior, no.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: You promise?

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Upon your word?

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: We'l talk some other time then.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: O! que Diavolo!

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Hola! Signior Scaramouch, let us discourse a little.

div.stage: Panc. goes after him, and takes him by the sleeve. Scaramouch returns.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: I say then, the Education of children.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Aye, the Education of children

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Is a thing not to be expected from every Father; for no one is fit to give Education to youth—
sp.stage: This is spoke at the same time that Pancrace speaks.
Enter Harlequin. Sees e'm both gabling together, comes and stands betwixt e'm, laughs, looks in their faces, and runs out.—
sp.p: But such as are of great Reason and Judgment. Hence it proceeds that so many Sons miscarry, because their Parents foolishly presuming on their own abilities, will be giving directions when they want it themselves: And how is it possible that any shou'd be well instructed, when he that will teach, needs to be taught. No, no, they who cannot give some eminent proof of their Abilities, ought rather to commit their Pupils to the care of those who are of known sufficiency, acd thorowly experienc'd in the Principles and Rudiments of—

div.stage: Enter Harl. with a Drum, stands betwixt e'm, and beats lowder and lowder; they turn from each other, and hold their ears. He goes out laughing.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Concurs so much to their This is spoke at the same time as that above. future being, that it is a duty incumbent on all Parents, to see e'm well brought up, and endoctrinated; for without Education our life is offensive to others, and a burthen to our selves; and Education consists principally in three points, First, in the Authority of him that instructs: Secondly, in his Care; and Thirdly, in his Ability: He must have Authority, or he is not regarded; for Youth is headstrong; he must have Care, because they are heedless; he must have Abilities, because many are indocile, and hard to be taught; and nothing but the soundness of his Reason can expel their Ignorance; which being innate and—

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Oh! so; Signior Scaramouch.

div.stage: Looks about, sees no-body, and turns to Scaramouch.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Signior.

div.stage: Pancracio stands in a posture leaning his ear, as listning to what Scar. will say; Scar does the same to him.—

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Speak.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Si.

div.stage: As they stand listning, Harl enters, stands betwixt 'em, looks in their faces; bursting into a little laughter, retreats, sings, and laughs.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Ha! he! he! he! hi!

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Signior Scaramoueh.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Ap— pouh.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Speak.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Ap— pouh

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Ah— he— he— hi!

div.stage: Harl. hits each a pat with his Sword on the Buttocks; as they each turn round,— he passes betwixt them, and goes out: they, in in turning, face each other.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Signior Scaramouch, what have you to say?

sp.speaker: Scarl.
sp.p: Nothing.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Nothing?

sp.speaker: Scarl.
sp.p: Nothing, Signior Pancrace, but that if your Son had had a discreet Father for his Instructor, he wou'd have known better things e're this, than making of Contracts and Marriages.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: But what if the Son of Signior Scaramouch, that has learnt the fine Accomplishments of Musick, Dancing, Fencing and Riding, and that has had such a wise Father to govern him, has done the like?

sp.speaker: Scarl.
sp.p: How, Signior Pancrace?

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Even so.

sp.speaker: Scarl.
sp.p: I understand not the Riddle.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Harlequin can explain it.— Adieu.

sp.speaker: Scarl.
sp.p: Done the like! O here he comes.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: Good-morrow to you Sir.

sp.speaker: Scarl.
sp.p: Octavio!

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Your Blessing.

sp.speaker: Scarl.
sp.p: No matter for Ceremony.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Are you unwilling to receive the tenders of my duty?

sp.speaker: Scarl.
sp.p: I have other business with you.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: What, Sir?

sp.speaker: Scarl.
sp.p: Stand before me, look me full in the face; fix your eyes upon my forhead.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: No Sir.

sp.speaker: Scarl.
sp.p: I read guilt in your looks.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: What do you mean Sir?

sp.speaker: Scarl.
sp.p: What horrid thing have you done?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Nothing, Sir, to offend you

sp.speaker: Scarl.
sp.p: Nothing?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Scarl.
sp.p: You'l not confess,— Harlequin says true.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Harlequin!

sp.speaker: Scarl.
sp.p: O, do you blush at that?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Has he told you any thing of me?

sp.speaker: Scarl.
sp.p: I'm in hast, look to't; if thou hast dishonour'd me, I'le renounce thee: And come not in my sight.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: O! Are you there, Sir? I'm glad to find your Worship.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Eh! your Servant, Sir; your Humble Servant, Signior Octavie.— I am your most Humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: You are very Ceremonious, but I shall spoil your Compliment, and let you understand,

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Ah! Signior Octavio!

div.stage: Octavio draws. Harl. falls on's knees.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: O! hold.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Pray don't hinder me.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Eh! Signior!

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: Signior Octavio.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Pray don't interpose.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: O! pray don't offer to—

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Eh!— How have I offended, in what?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: You are ignorant, are you?— I'le give you instructions, I will.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: Pray be pacify'd.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p:
Ho; I'l make the Rogue instantly confess his treachery;
yes Sirrah, I will: you thought it should never have been discover'd, but I'l have an open confession from thy own mouth, or run my Sword down your throat as deep as ever it was in the scabbard.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Ah! poor Harlequin, can you have the heart to—

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Confess then.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior, I confess I have offended you.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: O, have you so!

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Truly I have done you wrong, I confess it, Signior; but I don't know in what.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: I'l refresh your memory.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: No, no, Signior Octavio.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Well, Sir, since I must, I confess that my Companions and I drank up three of those six Flasks of Florence-Winae you sent to your Friend for a Present; when I told you that a Tile fell from the top of a House which was mending, and dropt just into my Basket, and broke 'em.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: O! did you drink it, Raseal, did you?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Yes Sir, and ask your pardon.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: I'm glad I know't. But this is not the thing I now question you about.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: This not the thing?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: No, 'tis a business that more neerly concerns me.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: I have done nothing else.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Have you not, Sir, have you not?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Eh!

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: Hold! hold!

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Eh! Signior, yes, yes: About a fortnight since, when you sent me one night to your Mistress, to Present her with the Gold-Watch, and I return'd cover'd over with dirt, and my face bloody, and told you that I was set upon by Rogues in the dark, as I went cross the square, who knockt me down, and rob'd me both of that and my Money—

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: So.—

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: It was all but invention, I went and sold it.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: You sold it, you did.—

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Yes, but can't imagine how you shou'd come to know't.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: A very good confession.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior, I wanted a small sum of Money.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: But this is not the thing neither I was resolv'd to know.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: No? oh! I am very sick, Signior.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: No, Villain, this is not it; but I'l make you out with it, or—

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: Hold.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Eh!— Well, Signior, you remember one night, as you came home from your Mistresses, that a Rogue came behind you, and knockt you down into the kennel with a great Club, and all spoil'd your new Clothes.—

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: 'Twas I, Signior, laid you sprawling, and then fell all along my self, as if I had been knockt down too, and cry'd out Thieves! Thieves!

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: It was your Roguery, yes.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Only, Signior, to make you keep better hours, and cause you to come home sooner a nights from your Mistresses, where you used to sit up late, and let me stand waiting for you without in the cold, to the great prejudice of my health.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: A precious servant, when time and place are more convenient, we'l talk more at large of these particulars; but at present I am only concern'd to know what thou hast lately done to me, yet worse than all this.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Not this neither.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: No, Sirrah!

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: This is all.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: This all?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signiorsi.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: No, Sirrah, this is not all, and I'l not leave thee till thou hast confest the very thing.

sp.speaker: Aarl.
sp.p: But will you leave me then?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: But confess.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Eh! Signior, tell me what 'tis, and I'l confess with all! my heart.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Quick, Sirrah, quick; I'm in hast.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Let it alone till another time, and I'l think on't against I see you next.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Sirrah, one minutes delay, and thou art dead.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Eh! Signior Octavio; Mercy, Signior, I have told you all.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: This all?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signiorsi.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: You'l not confess then what you told my Father?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Your Father! yes—

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Nothing.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Nothing?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior, no.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: No?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: ‛ Signior, no.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Look to't, I had it from his own mouth.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior, with your permission, Heaven won't bless him, if he tells lies.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: If I find you did, I'l cut your throat as sure—

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Sir, I bring you ill news.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: What, Plautino?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Cut my throat! Signior, no; Signior Octavio, Servitore.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: The Egyptians are upon going away with your Zerbinetta, and she, with tears in her eyes, charg'd me to come with all speed▪ to acquaint you, that if you don't come and bring the Money (within two hours) which the Company demand for her, you will lose her for ever; for they intend for Germany.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: Within two hours!

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: At farthest.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: Without thy aid, Plautino, I am wretched. If thou hast no invention to procure the Sum, I'm undone for ever.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: How much is't?

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: Five hundred Ducats.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: And I am ruin'd too, if thou canst not procure me 200 Pistols.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: I have a Mint in my Brain, and I'l coin so much for you both presently.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: But time presses the performance.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: I'l make both your Fathers Purses bleed for't. As for your business, the Engine is already fitted. Well, let's about our design: Where's Harlequin? he must make one.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: Your threats have made him desert us.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: He'l be a necessary Impliment.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: I'l endeavour to regain him before he's got quite out of our reach.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: His fear will make him avoid you.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: I'l hunt him out.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: I'l have no more to do with young men; I'l apply my self to the old, that are grave and serious. I'l go and consult with Signior Pancrace, the learn'd Doctor, to know how I shall be a wise man. Hola! Signior Doctore!

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Your Servant, Signior Doctore.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: O ho! Harlequin, what news?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior Pancrace, I have a mind to be a Philosopher.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: I am vext that my Father and Mother did not breed me up to be a Scholar when I was young.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: A very rational reflections; Nam sine Doctrina vita est quasi mortis Imago; You know what that is, you understand Latin?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Yes, but in a manner as it were that I did not. Tell me the meaning of't▪ I pray.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: That is to say; Without learning, life is but the Image of death.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: I find this Latin has much of truth in't. Pray give me your instructions. for I have a mind to be one of your Sect.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: You have the Foundation of Knowledg already, the Principles and Rudiments of Learning.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Eh; yes, yes, I can write and read.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: What is it you have most mind to learn? Logick?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Logick! what is Logick?

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Logick is that which directeth the three operations of the understanding.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: The three operations of the understanding! what be they?

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p:
The first, the second, and the third; the first is, to apprehend
well by the means of the Universals. The second is▪ to judg well by means of the Categories. The third is, to draw a consequence well by means of the Figures, Barbara, Celarent, Darii, Ferio, Baralipton, &c.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: He's Conjuring.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Come near.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: What are these, the names of Spirits, or of Heathen Philosophers?

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: The names of Figures, the chief things in Logick?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Logick then I find is full of cramp-words; teach me something that is not so crabbid, something that I may learn with pleasure.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Have you a mind to learn Morals?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Morals! what's the meaning of Morals?

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Moral Philosophy treats of Happiness, teaches men to moderate their Passions, and—

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Eh; Signior, no; I can't moderate my passions; when I am vext, I am as angry as the Devil in Hell, and hearken to no manner of reason, therefore Morals will be in vain.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Wou'd you then learn Physicks, or Natural Philosophy?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: What is that about?

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: It explicates the Principles of natural things, and the Proprieties of bodies: It discourses of the nature of the Elements, Metals, Minerals, Stones, Plants, and Animals: and teaches the cause of Meteors, of the Rainbow, of Comets, Lightnings, Thunder, of Rain, Snow, Hail, of Winds, Tempests, and Earthquakes.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: There's too much hurry in this, it makes too great a din●in a man's ears, and giddies his brain.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Meta-Physicks then?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Meta-Physicks, Signior! Meta-Physicks?

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Treats of Heaven, and Angels, of Spirits and—

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: No, I'l have nothing to do with Spirits.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: What wou'd you learn then?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Teach me to spell well, that I may write so, as people may know what it means.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Oh, Orthography!

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Yes, Orthography.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: O, very well; have you e're a Primmer?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: I learn the Primmer!

sp.speaker: Panc,
sp.p: Yes, 'tis very requisite for a man that will be a Philosopher, to understand the Primmer well.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: I was a Philosopher twenty years ago then. Teach me something that is mighty fine to know, something that is very curious, that I may pass for one deeply learn'd. Teach me to understand the Almanack.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: The Almanack?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Yes, that I may know how many days are in a week, how many weeks in a month, how many months in a year.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: How to know when Quarter-day comes, and how often in a year: that I may be sure never to lose any of my wages.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Good! so.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: That I may know when the Wind blows, or does not blow; when it rains, or not rains; or when the Moon shines, or does not shine.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Things very material, and necessary to be learnt: sollow me, and I'l carry you to a fine old Gentlewoman that lives hard-by, who shall instruct you.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Is she a Philosopher, Signiore?

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: A profound one, and deeply skill'd in the Primmer, and the Almanack. Come, I'l recommend you to her, and she shall take pains with you.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Your Servant, Signiore Pancrace.

div.trailer: The End of the second Act.

div.head: Act III. Scene I. A School-Room.
div.stage: The Scene draws, and discovers Harlequin amongst a company of little children at School, all gabling together in a Schooltone; the Mistress sitting in the middle in a great Chair, with a great Rod and a Ferrula sticking upright at either corner of the back o'the Chair. Harl. snatches a piece of Bread and Butter out of one of the childrens hands; the child falls a crying.

sp.speaker: 3d Sch.
sp.p: EUnh! Eunh! Eunh!

sp.speaker: Mistr.
sp.p: How now? who's that makes a noife: there?

sp.speaker: 1st Sch.
sp.p: The new Scholar.

sp.speaker: 2d Sch.
sp.p: The new Scholar.

sp.speaker: Mist.
sp.p: Child, come hither; what makes you cry, tell me?

sp.speaker: 3d Sch.
sp.p: H'has got my Bread and Butter.

sp.speaker: Mist.
sp.p: Cuds-lidikins, he; which is that he?

sp.speaker: 3d Sch.
sp.p: He there.

sp.speaker: Mist.
sp.p: My new Scholar! does he play such tricks already?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: I was very hungry, Signiora Philosopher.

sp.speaker: Mist.
sp.p: I shall teach you better manners.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: I ask'd for a piece, and the cross Chit wou'd give me none.

sp.speaker: Mist.
sp.p: And therefore you were so rude to snatch it?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: I had not eat my Breakfast to day.

sp.speaker: Mist.
sp.p: Look you do so no more.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Mayn't a Philosopher eat Bread and Butter?

sp.speaker: Mist.
sp.p: Come, which of all you Dunces that stay behind here, can say your Lessons, that you may go home after your fellows?

sp.speaker: All Sch.
sp.p: I, I, I, I, I, I.

sp.speaker: Mist.
sp.p:
Look to't, they that tell me they can, if they can't,
shall be whipt; therefore sit you down, and mind your Books till I come agen, that you may be perfect.

div.stage: Harlequin goes and sits in the Mistresses Chair, takes the Rod and plays with it; pulls out an Apple, and eats and sings with his mouth full.

sp.speaker: 1st, 2d, 3d. Sch.
sp.p: O brave! O brave!

sp.speaker: 1st Sch.
sp.p: I'l tell my Mistress.

sp.speaker: 2d Sch.
sp.p: I'l tell my Mistress.

sp.speaker: 1st, 2d, 3d Sch.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: You, little boy, come hither, and say your Lesson.

sp.speaker: 1st Sch.
sp.p: Pray, who are you?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: I'm a Philosopher.

sp.speaker: 1st Sch.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! A Philosopher! Pray, Mr. Philosopher, come out of my Mistresses Chair.

div.stage: They throw Books at him, and pull him to come out.

sp.speaker: All Sch.
sp.p: Ay, come out of the Chair, come out.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: I'm a Philosopher! I'm a Philosopher! I'm a Philosopher!

div.stage: Enter Mistress. They all run to their places. Harl. sees the Mistress, and runs to her.

sp.speaker: Mist.
sp.p: So, what's to do here?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: O que Diavolo!

sp.speaker: Mist.
sp.p: This is fine! my back's no sooner turn'd, but you are all at your Gambols: Come, for this trick, he that has not his Lesson perfect, shall be sent home with a good whipping: and first, let's see what you can do, you, Mr. Philosopher.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signiora!

sp.speaker: Mist.
sp.p: Come, and stand by my Chair; so, stand upright. How chance you han't wash'd your hands to day?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: O! no matter.

sp.speaker: Mist.
sp.p: No matter, said you?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: I forgot it.

sp.speaker: Mist.
sp.p: Forget to wash 'em another morning, and I'l scour 'em for you with a good Rod.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Ha! ha! he!

sp.speaker: Mist.
sp.p: Out, you great sloven; come to School with dirty-hands!

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Euh, Signiora! well enough, well enough.

sp.speaker: Mist.
sp.p: Well enough! but let me sind it so agen, and it shall be ill enough with you.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Mayn't a Philosopher have dirty-hands?

sp.speaker: Mist.
sp.p: Look I see't no more so.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: What does Mrs. Philosopher concern her self so with my hands, for?

sp.speaker: Mist.
sp.p: Come, let me hear you say your Lesson now. Shut your Book, say over the Alphabet, begin.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: A, b, c, d, e, f, g, h, i, k, l, m, n, p.

sp.speaker: Mist.
sp.p: N, p! what's the next letter to N?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: P.

sp.speaker: Mist.
sp.p: P, agen? there's the second fault; hold out your hand.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: My hand?

sp.speaker: Mist.
sp.p: Hold it out to receive instruction, thus; so, now look on the top of the house, and see what letter sticks on the Seeling.

div.stage: He holds out his hand, she hits him with a Ferrula.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: O!

sp.speaker: Mist.
sp.p: O then is the next letter, l, m, n, o. This, I see, will make you a Scholar.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: I find 'tis as Mr. Doctore said, she's a profound Philosopher.

sp.speaker: Mist.
sp.p: N, O, P; then go on.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: N, O, P, Q, R, S, T, U, W, X, Y, Z.

sp.speaker: Mist.
sp.p: How, open your Book, and read.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: A, b, ab, e, b, eb, i, b, ib, o, b, ob, u, b, ub. B, a, ab.

sp.speaker: Mist.
sp.p: How's that? b, a, spell ab?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mist.
sp.p: A, b, spells ab; B, a, spells— what? what says the Sheep?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: What says a Sheep? Ha! ha! ha! he!

sp.speaker: Mist.
sp.p: What says the Sheep?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: The Sheep says— Ha! ha! he! nothing can a Sheep speak.

sp.speaker: Mist.
sp.p: Did you never hear a Sheep cry Ba?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Ba? yes.

sp.speaker: Mist.
sp.p: Well then, B, a, spells Ba; this is the third fault▪ Come, a sound whipping will quicken your apprehension.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Ha, ha, he.

sp.speaker: Mist.
sp.p: I am glad to see you so chearful; come, put your head through the back o'this Chair.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: What means Mrs. Phisosopher?

sp.speaker: Mist.
sp.p: Come down, down, I say—

div.stage: Hits his hand with a Rod▪

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Eh,— Eh,— Mrs. Philosopher.

sp.speaker: Mist.
sp.p: How long must I stand waiting on you? Down, down, I say.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Eh,— Eh,— Mrs. Philosopher.—

sp.speaker: Mist.
sp.p: Down with your head.—

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Eh, Eh.

sp.speaker: Mist.
sp.p: So, children, one of you untruss his Points quickly.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Ha, whipt! whip a Philosopher? Eh,— Eh,— Mrs. Philosopher, Mrs. Philosopher.

sp.speaker: Mist.
sp.p: Untruss, untruss, does he resist; here, every one of you take a Rod, and help me.

div.stage: Harl. puts his head through the back o'the Chair, lifts it up, runs about the Room with it hanging on his neck; all the children take Rods, and, with the Mistress, run about the Stage whipping him. He runs out, the Scene shuts.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Eh,— Eh,— Eh, Signiora Mrs. Philosopher, Signiora▪ Mrs. Philosopher. Eh, Eh, Eh.—

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Whipt! a Pox o' Mrs. Philosopher. Whipt! Devil take Mrs. Philosopher. O! here comes Signior Scaramouch; I'l go and consult with him. Signior Scaramouch!

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Harlequin!

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior Scaramouch, I am disgusted with the affairs o'the World, and resolve to apply my self to other things. I have a desire to be a Philosopher.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: A Philosopher?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior si.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Hola!— within there! Prepare▪ the habit of a Novitiate; go, go, into the Hall, and they'l put you on the habit of a Novitiate.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: A Novitiate! no, no, of a Philosopher.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Of a Philosopher of the first Class.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: First Class! what's that?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Of a Novice.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: O ho! of the Sect of the Novice Philosopher.

div.stage: Goes into the house, and re-enters.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Go, 'tis ready for you. So, now you have assum'd the Robes of a Philosopher, 'tis requisite your mind shou'd be invested too with the habits of a Philosopher.

div.stage: Enter Harl. in a great Gown of Mat, with Hanging-sleeves of the same, and a broad Straw-hat, with one half of the brim pull'd under his chin, parting from the head.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior si.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: The habits then requisite for the mind are these.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: By the way, one word, I pray, Signior Scaramouch; are the habits of the mind for a Philosopher, made of the same stuff as the habits of his body? Methinks this shou'd be a little too coarse for the in-side.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: A habit is a certain▪ facility added to our power, and helping it to act.— As for example,— a—

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: A certain facility!

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: As for example.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: A certain ●a,—

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Eh! As for example, a Rope-dancer, who by often practising to dance upon a Rope, grows at last expert, and does it with ease.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: So I, by often wearing my new Shooes—

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Wore 'em out.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Euh,— Peuh.—

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior Scaramouch, hear me now: A habit is a certain facility added to our power, and helping it to act. As for example, a Rope-dancer, who by often dancing upon the Rope, at last breaks his neck with case▪

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: O stupidity! the principal vertues requisite in a Philosopher, are Patience, Temperance, Sobriety and Chastity; the first is Patience, he must not be provoked to anger.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: If I am struck by any one, may I not strike agen?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: No! If a Mule kick me, may I not kick agen?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: No! I'l be no Philosopher.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Not unless you can kick harder than him.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: O ho! then if any one strike me▪ I may strike agen, if I think I can beat him. Cud-so! I find there's reason in Philosophy.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: The next is Temperance; a Philosopher must be temperate, he must not eat much.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Not eat much?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: No, eating dulls the brain.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Not eat much!

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: No! I'l be no Philosopher.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Not much Mutton, or Beef, nor such gross meat, but good Capons,— Partridg,— and Pheasant.—

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: O ho! Pray go on.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: The next is Sobriety; a Philosopher must not be drunk, nor given to drink.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Mayn't a Philosopher drink?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Not much.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: No, I'l be no Philosopher.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Unless.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: No, no, unless I may drink as much as I please, I'l be no Philosopher.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: No Philosopher!

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: No, I love good Wine.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: You must not drink sour, naughty, crude Wines, but the best you can get; as Monti-Pulchino, Montifiasco, and Florence Wines.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: O ho!

sp.speaker: Scar▪
sp.p: Be sure the Wine you drink, be good.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: O, I'm of your opinion, Signior; I find I shall soon be a Philosopher, because I come of the kind; my Mother was a Philosopher; for the knew what was good for her; she always kept the best for her self.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: The last is, Chastity; you must not run after Women.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Nor mayn't they come to me?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: I'l be no Philosopher.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Hold.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Mayn't I lye with them neither?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: I'l be no Philosopher.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Not unless you are marri'd▪

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Not unless I am marri'd!

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: And then too with great moderation.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: I'l be no Philosopher.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Hold.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Mayn't I now and then, when I've got Money, go to a Wench?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Not if I'm sure she be sound?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Upon no account.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: No; I'l be no Philosopher, I'l be no Philosopher.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Hold, hold, hold.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: No, no; I'l be no Philosopher, no Philosopher; I'l be no Philosopher.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Euh! Que Bestia, Bruto, Animale.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Philosopher; a Pox take Philosophers; I'l be no more a Philosopher: Not to go to a Wench! Eh, he, he.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: He's here.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Eh, Signior Octavio, here!

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: Nay, you can't avoid us now.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Euh, Signior, I demand pardon.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Harlequin, you must along with me, now is the time for you to shew your Parts.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Euh, Signior Octavio; I demand pardon.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Come, think of my instructions, and let's see how well you can perform, after the pains I have taken with you.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: My dear Harlequin, listen to his discourse.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Ah ha! now, dear Harlequin, now you have need of me.

div.stage: Starts up, and walks huffing about.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Go, I pardon all thou hast confest, and worse yet, if thou hast don't.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: No, Signior, no; don't pardon me, run me through, kill me; I shall tak't for an Honour to dye by so noble a hand.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: No, Merit rewards by being assistant to my love.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: No, Signior, kill me; Signior, kill me.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: I'l forget thou ever didst offend me.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Kill me, Signior, kill me.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: I'l never be angry with thee hereafter, do what thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Kill me, Signior, kill me.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: No, I have too great a love for thee, my poor dear Harlequin; come, be good natur'd.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: To surprise me, and so to affront me.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: Come, come, forget and forgive.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: To call me so many Rogues and Villains.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: It was my passion.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: To offer to run your Sword down my throat.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Eh, Harlequin.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: To make me bring to light the secrets that had long lain buri'd under the Tombstone of my heart.—

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: I am sorry for't.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: To make me discover what I had sworn never to reveal.—

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: I ask thee pardon, my dear Harlequin be pacifi'd, take pitty of a poor Lover,

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: This ought to mollify.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Well, you'l never take me to Confession agen?—

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Nor kill me?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Nor run me through?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Nor thrust your Sword down my throat?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Harl.
