sp.p: Well then, I pardon you.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Go then, prepare to come forth with all speed; all things are in readiness, be gone.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Allagre, Signior Octavio, Allagre.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: O, here comes Signior Pancrace chewing the cud; be gone, and leave me to proceed in my Enterprise. Take care of my reserve, and hasten him into the field.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p:
T' have so little conduct and consideration, to throw
himself into such a snare as this!— O! the unadvisedness of youth!

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Sir, your Servant.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: How do you, Plautino?

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: You are thinking of your Son.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: It gives me no small trouble.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Life is full of changes; it is good always to be prepar'd for the worst.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: I cou'd ha' born any thing but this.

sp.speaker: Plaut,
sp.p: Every one can bear the evils which might have hapned; but 'tis the part of a Philosopher to master his Temper, and command his Passions in the evils which do happen.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: I'l tell you, Mr. Plautino, nothing but this cou'd have mov'd me:— This is a thing;— Well, I'm just going to Counsel about it, to know how to remedy it.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Pray hearken to me, Signior Pancrace; try some other way to adjust the business, you are not ignorant that Law requires much sawce, and you will hang your self upon dangerous Tenters.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: You are in the right; but pray what is that other way?

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: I went and found out the Brother of this young Woman your Son has marri'd; he is by profession a Bravo, one that lives by cutting of throats; he never speaks without an Oath in's mouth, and makes no more scruple to kill a man, than to blow out the snuff of a Candle. I discours'd him upon the Marriage, and found him reasonably inclin'd to accommodate the business for a certain Sum of Money; and provided he may have it, he's contented to suffer a Divorce.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: What is't he demands?

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Oh! 'tis very considerable.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: But what?

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Extravagant things.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Well, let me hear?

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Nothing under 5 or 600 Pistols.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Five or 600 l evors and Quartan-Agues seize him! he does it to jeer us.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p:
So I told him I wou'd not give ear to such a Proposition, and said that you was not a man of that easy temper to be whistled out of your Money: After a long debate, the result
was this;— I am, says he, in a short time, to go to the Army in Flanders; I must be well accoutred, and have need of Money, which makes me consent to what otherwise I shou'd not hearken to: I want a good serviceable Horse for the Wars, which will not cost less than threescore Pistols.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Well, threescore Pistols shall break no squares.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: I shall want too, says he, a Sword, Pistols, Scarf and Feather; which will cost at least thirty Pistols more.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Thirty and threescore, make fourscore and ten.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Just.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: 'Tis a great Sum, but for once I'l be content, because you advise me.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: I shall want too, says he, a Horse for my Man, which will cost thirty Pistols.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: A Horse for his Man?

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Let him walk a-foot, and be hang'd! a Horse for his Man! Pox on him, he shall have none.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: But, Sir?

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: No, he's an impertinent Rascal! A Horse for his Man!

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Auh, fye, Sir! what, wou'd you have the Servant 〈◊〉 a Cavalier go a-foot?

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: E'ne let him go as he please, and the Master too. A Horse for his Man!

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Come, Sir, ne'r stick out for so small a matter; don't go to intangle your self in Law: give it, give it, to save the trouble of going to Law.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Ha, well;— Since you will have it so, I will. But he's a Rogue! a great Rogue! a Horse for his Man! a Pox on him; they shall neither of 'em have one for me.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Signior Pancrace; a Philosopher, and recall his words!

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Well then, Signior Plautino, because I said it, I'l stand to't.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: I must have too, says he, a Sumpter-Horse to carry—

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: O! let him go to the Devil with his Sumpter-Horse, I'l to Law.

sp.speaker: Plaut▪
sp.p: Ah! consider, Sir!

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: No, no Sumpter-Horse.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: What, not a little Mule?

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: No, I'l to Law.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Consider, Signior Pancrace.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: No, no, I'l to Law.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Ah! not a little paltry Mule?

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: I'l to Law, I'l to Law.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Of some 8 or 10 Pistols price.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: No, no, 3 or 4 Crowns it may be, to buy him a little Ass.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: What, Sir; an Ass to carry his Luggage to the Wars?

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Then I'l to Law.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: No, pray don't talk of going to Law: there will be Money for Declarations, Pleas, Answers, Rejoynders, Sub-Rejoynders, Demurs, Motions, Non-Suits, and Removing from one Court to another: Then your Appeals. Eh!— if once you entangle your self, you'l sooner see the end of your Estate, than of your Suit of Law.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: And what, I pray, will this Sumpter-Beast cost?

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: For his Horse, his Man's, and the Sumpter-Horse; and for the Pistols, Sword, Scarf and Feather, with Bridles, Saddles, and other Furniture, and to pay some dribling Debts which he owes to his Landlady, Laundress, and so forth; he demands in all, 200 Pistols.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Two hundred Pistols?

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Two hundred Pistols. I'l to Law, to Law.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Bethink your self.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: I'l to Law.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Don't embroil your self.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: I say I'l to Law.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: You must spend a world of Money in Law; you must give the Clerks Expedition-Money, pay for Writing, Drawing, Engrossing, Copying, Sealing, Endorsing, and all several Charges. Then for Fees in Court, Judges Fees, King's Duties. Then, Sir, what's most requisite of all, Bribing of Judges: your Adversary too does the like. So that after all, 'tis but Cross and Pile who gets the better. O! Signior Pancrace, Law-expences are numberless; give this Fellow his Money, and there's an end; 'tis easier to satisfy one Rogue than a thousand.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Give him 200 Pistols!

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Yes, and be a gainer by't. I've cast up what a Suit of Law amounts to; and I find, that giving him 200 Pistols, will save you five; not reckoning your trouble, pains, vexations, going, waiting, sending, fetching and carrying, and following a company of busy Coxcombs, who will but laugh at you when you ha' done. I wou'd rather give 500 Pistols than go to Law, tho I were sure to get the better.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Laugh at the learn'd, I defy 'em.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Signior Pancrace, you may do as you please; but were it to me, I'd give 200 Pistols, and laugh at them.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: No, I'l to Law, I'l to Law.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Here comes the Gentleman himself.

div.stage: Enter Harlequin in the habit of a Bravo, with a huge Sword, and a Girdle stuck round with Pistols and Daggers, which are discover'd by▪ his Cloak falling off;— and Rosy-Cheeks, with great Whiskers.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior Plautino, carry me to this Dog of a Dr. to this damn'd Heathen Philosopher, this old Rogue, the Father of Cynthio.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: For what, Signiot Cavalier?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: I hear he's for going to Law, and for getting a Divorce against my Sister! I'l divorce him! I'l divorce his Soul from his Body!

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: I know not whether he intends any such thing.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: I hear he does, carry me to him; I'l make a Woodcock of the Philosopher. Pick a hole in his Skull, and sup up his Brains for my Breakfast.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: He'd make no more to do't, than to sup off a RawEgg. I heard indeed he will not consent to give you 200 Pistols, he says 'tis too much.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Death, and Heart! if I find him, I'll dissect him; tho I'm broken alive upon the Wheel as soon as 'tis done.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Signior Pancrace is a man of Resolution, and perhaps does not fear you, nor any man that wears a head.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: He,— he not fear me! Death, and Heart! if I find him, with this Sword I'l rip him from the Belly up to the Chin. Who '! is he there?

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: O Signior! that's none of him, that's none of him.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Nor no Friend of his?

sp.speaker: Plrut.
sp.p: On the contrary, the greatest enemy he has.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: I am glad o'that of my Soul: Signior, are you an enemy to that Logical, Moral, Phisical, Meta-phisical Philosopher? that Syllogistical Dunder▪ noll Doctor? Ounds! are you his enemy? ha!

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Yes, Signior; I'l assure you he is.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Give me thy hand then, old Trojan; I swear to thee by my Reputation, by ten thousand Devils, and all their Dams, before two days are at an end, I'l whet my Sword upon the bones of him. Therefore fet your heart at rest, and let me alone to revenge all; I'l send his Soul to the Devil, throw his Carkass to the Dogs, and bring you his Brains in a Mustard pot; Damnation! I will Boy!— Eh!—

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Such things are not suffer'd here.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Ounds! I'm a Souldierly Philosopher, and carry all my wealth about me; my Sword is my Plough, and another Countrey will serve for Tillage as well as this.— For the death of him I will be, tho his Soul, by transmigration, goes presently into a wild Bull, and he bears me away upon his Horns.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: He has heard of your threatning, and will be upon his guard; he has many Friends, Acquaintance, and Servants, that will desend him.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Let 'em come, let 'em come, a thousand of 'em; 'tis what I desire. S'death!— Heart!— and Ounds!— Oh! that he were but here now, in the midst of twenty friends and all their Swords in their hands; Eh,— you Rogues, you Dogs, come on! Allone! Morblieu! Sa, sa; Kill, kill; no quarter; Slash,— cut, thrust,— kill,— stand fast;— Eh! you cowardly Rogues, you Dogs, you Sons of Whores! Have at you,— at you,— at you,— at you,— at you! Do you give ground? Stand fast, you Dogs; fast! Ha!— Eh!—

div.stage: Pushes on all sides with his Sword.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Eh!— Eh!— Eh!— We are none of 'em, Sir.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Ha! do you rally agen? are there more of you? Have amongst you!
There's for you! Thus wou'd I ha' serv'd 100 of 'em.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: You see how many throats he'd cut for 200 Pistols. I wish you were well out of this business.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Plautino.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Signior.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: He shall have 200 Pistols.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: I am glad on't, for your sake.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Call him, I have so much about me.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Give 'em me, 'twill not be for your Honour to see him, now you have past for another; and I fear, if he shou'd get you in his power, he wou'd stand upon greater matters.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Hold your hand, but take care my business be done fore you part from my Money.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: I'l go home and expect your coming; be sure you see it done.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Trouble not your self, I'l bring you a good account how I part from't.— So, here's one Bird catch'd in chaff.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: Have you done any thing to the comfort of a poor Lover?

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: See, there are 200 drops of your Father's hearts-blood.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: Witty Plautino, what comfort thou giv'st me! Come, let's haste to purchase what I value more than life. Now! my lov'd Zerbinetta! thou art mine!

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Octavio comes not yet near me; 'tis so,— he has done something;— I'l go find him out, and make him confess the business.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: O, Signior Philosopher! O, Signior Scaramouch!

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: What, what?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Your Son.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Well, my Son.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Has the greatest misfortune befallen him; alas poor Mr. Octavio.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: What? ha!

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p:
I sound him in a very melancholly mood, for something you had said to him; and to divert his thoughts, we took a
walk to the Sea-side; where, amongst other things, I saw a Fisherman going out; we went a-board for pastime, to see some sport. When we were a league off at Sea, a small Vessel made up to us; we suspected nothing, but when they came they boarded us; took us all out of the Fisher-man, and clapt us under Hatches.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Octavio too?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior si, they were Pyrats, Runagado-Rogues; they have sent me a-shoar in a long-Boat, to tell you that if you don't immediately send 'em 500 Dollers, they'l carry your Son away to Algiers.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Five hundred Dollers?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Yes, and have allow'd me but two hours for my return.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: What a murrain made him go a fishing?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Eh,— Signior Scaramouch; a Philosopher can bear injuries as he ought.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: They demand, you say—

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Five hundred Dollers.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Think they that's a Sum one wou'd be content to part from?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: They are great fools.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: And that I have nothing to do with my Money but to send it to them?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Pyrats, Signior, are a sort of folks that don't understand Philosophy.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Four hundred Dollars, say you?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Five hundred, Signior.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Five hundred?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Yes Sir, but make hast. Hold your hand. Go and ransom my Son.

div.stage: He holds the Purse, and talks, which he does not let go, and carries his arm from one side to t'other. Harl. does the like.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: But tell these Pyrats that they are Rascals.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Rogues.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Great Rogues, Thieves, Cut-throats.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Let me alone.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: They get these 500 Dollers from me against my will.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: And which I wou'd not ha' given them to save their lives.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Very good.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: And that if ever it lies in my power, I'l be reveng'd.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Go make hast, and bring my Son a-shoar.

div.stage: Puts the Purse in's pocket, and is going away.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: But, Signior.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Where's the Money?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Han't you't.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Not I, you put it up agen in your pocket.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: I know not what I do, I'm so vext.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Twou'd vex a man—

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: What a murrain made him go a fishing?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Ha! ha! he! Signior Philosopher!

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Harlequin.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior Philosopher; Ha! ha! he!

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: I find thou hast good news, thou art so merry?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior, no.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Can'st thou do nothing for me?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior, no.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Must I then despair?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: I have done all I can.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Do'st thou give me comfort?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior, no; the Stars are unlucky.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: I will then find out a place for my retreat; lye down, and sigh away my life.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Stay, Signior Octavio, here's luck in a bag for you.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Thou shewest me life, health, and all.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: How, call me names, and run your Sword down my throat!

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: No more of that, I have forgot it.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: I part with this Money, on condition that you give me leave to be reveng'd on Signior Scaramouch, for what he said of me.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Do as thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: There then's your Sum.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: I'l hast to tell Aurelia this good news.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: And I to be reveng'd on Signior Philosopher.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: So affected with Gallantry! such a Lover of Balls, Masques, and other Divertisements! I have been all this while mistaken in her humour, I'l not concern my self at what she does, or where she goes! can this be wholsome to a Husband's Reputation! Well, I will hear what the learned will say on this point. And first, I'l consult with Signior Pancracio.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Go, go friend, you are very impertinent, and ought to be banish'd the Republick of Letters.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Oh! here he cames to my purpose.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Yes, and not without very good reason: I say you are a Dunce, a Blockhead, an Ignorant; an Ignorantior, an Ignorantissimus, an Ignorantissimetissimus, an Ignoramus per omnes Casus, Moods and Tenses.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: He has been wrangling with somebody in a Disputation▪ Signior.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: You will be arguing, and know not so much as the very Rudiments of Learning.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Passion blinds him so, he sees me not, Signior.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: 'Tis a Proposition condemn'd, confuted, rejected by all Philosophers both Ancient and Modern.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Somebody has much incens'd him,— I—

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Toto Coelo, Toto via aberras.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: I kiss your hands, Signior Pancrace.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Servant, Servant.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Can I—

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Do you know what you have done! A Syllogism in Bocardo.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: I desire—

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: The Major's absurd, the Minor's impertinent, and the Conclusion ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: I desi—

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: I'd sooner dye than grant what you say, and I'l defend my opinion to the last drop of my Ink.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Can I—

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Yes, I'l defend this Proposition; ●gunis & calcibus, unguibus & rostro.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Signior Aristotle, pray what has so incens'd you?

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: I have all the reason in the World.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Pray what was't?

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: An illiterate Blockhead, wou'd maintain an erronious Proposition; a false, damnable, destructive, execrable Proposition.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: May I beg leave to know what 'twas?

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Ah! Signior Spittzaferro, nature is this day reverst, and the World is falling to a general decay, a most shameful License reigns every where, and the Magistrates who are establisht to take care of the Publick, ought to blush for shame, in suffering such a horrible and intolerable Scandal as this.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: What, pray?

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Is it not a most horrible thing, a thing that cries to Heaven for vengeance, that it shou'd be suffer'd, for a man publickly to cry the form of a Hat?

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: How's that?

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: I maintain that a man ought to say the figure of a Hat, and not the form; yes, not forma, but figura; for there is this difference betwixt form and figure, that the form is the external disposition of animate Bodies; the figure is the external dispositions of Bodies inanimate: It ought to be said, the figure of a Hat, and not the form. Go-to, Dunce as thou art, this is the truth of the thing, these are the express terms of Aristotle, in his Chapter of Quality.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Marry, I thought we had been all undone! Come, Signior Pancrace, think no more of this; I have a business to impart to you. I desire—

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: O, impertinent Blockhead!

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Pray forget it. I desi—

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Dunce.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: I beseech you, Sir,— I— de—

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: To defend against me such a Proposition as this.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: He was in the wrong,— I—

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: A Proposition condem'd by Aristotle.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: That's true,— I—

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: In express terms—

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p:
Y'are in the right; yes,— you are a Fool, a Dunce, an
Ouff, a Sot, a Blockhead, to dispute against a Learn'd Doctor that can both write and read,— So now the business is over, I desire you'd give me your attention; I come to consult with you about a business which very much puzzles me, I have thoughts of Marrying, to have a Companion in the business of the World; the person is handsome, and I like her very well: she thinks her self a happy Woman to have me for a Husband; her Father and I are agreed: But I'm a little startled at a thing that you may guess— of a blow that a man never feels when 'tis given him. And I desire you, as being a Philosopher, to tell me your opinion. How, what do you advise me too?

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Sooner than I wou'd accord to say the form of a Hat, I wou'd be brought to affirm, that datur vacuum in rerum natura; and that I am not a Man, but a Vegetable, a Plant, or a four footed Beast.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Doubtless he's possest; Mr. Doctor, pray hear me a little; I have been speaking to you this half hour, and you don't mind what I say.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: I beg your pardon, I am so incens'd when I hear the truth oppugn'd.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Well, Sir, forget it, and give me your attention.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Very good;— what wou'd you with me, good Signior Spittzaferro?

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: I wou'd speak to you concerning a business.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: In what, Idiom?

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Idiom!

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: In what Language wou'd you discourse; in French?

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Spanish?

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Dutch?

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: English?

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Latin?

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Greek?

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Hebrew?

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Syriack?

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Arabick?

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Chaldea?

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Turkish?

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: No, no, no; in Italian, in Italian.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Oh! in Italian?

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Go then on t'other side, for this ear is destin'd only to Scientifical Languages; and this for my Mother-tongue.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: What a deal of Ceremony there is with these Learn'd Men.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Well, now tell me what you wou'd have?

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: I wou'd have your opinion concerning a difficulty.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: A Philosophical difficulty, without doubt.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Excuse me,— I—

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Perhaps you wou'd know if Substance and Accident be terms synonimus, or equivocal, in respect of being.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Not at all, Signior.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: If Logick be an Art or a Science?—

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Not that neither I—

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: If it has for its objects the three operations of the understanding, or only the third?

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: No,— I—

sp.speaker: Pauc.
sp.p: If there be ten Categories, or only one?

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Not I— I—

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: If the Conclusion be of the Essence of eight Syllogisms.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: No, no,— I.

sp.speaker: Aanc.
sp.p: If the essence of good consists in the Appetibility, that is in being desirable, or in being convenient?

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: No, that I—

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: If good be reciprocal with the end?

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Peu! Ho! I—

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: If the end can move us by its real being, or by the intentional, that is, by the being it has in our apprehensions?

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: No, no, no, a Pox o'the Devil; none of all this.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Explain your self then, for I can't guess what 'tis.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Aye, Aye, Signior, I wou'd explain my self; but you must hear me then: The business that I wou'd discourse with you about, is this: That I have some thoughts of Marrying a Gentlewoman, that is young and handsome, and one who has a kindness for me; and I have ask'd her Fathers consent. But now I apprehend—

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p:
Speech is given to a man At the same time. to explain his thoughts; and just as thoughts are the representations of things, so are our words the representations of our thoughts. But those representations are distinguish'd from
others, in-as-much as other representations are altogether distinguish'd from their originals; and words include in themselves their originals, they being nothing else but the thoughts explicated by external signs; from whence it comes, that those who think well, do also speak well. Now therefore explain your thoughts to me by your words, which are, of all signs, the most intelligible.

div.stage: Spittz. pushes the Doctor into his house, and returns.

sp.speaker: Spittz.
sp.p: The Devil take all such folks as won't hear a man speak: I'l go find out the other Philosopher; he perhaps may be more reasonable, and less talkative.

div.stage: Panc. comes out agen, and Spittz. pushes him in.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Now, Aristotle says there is this difference—

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Are you there agen with your Aristotle? Go, your Master Aristotle's a Fool, and you are an Ass.

div.trailer: The End of the third Act.

div.head: Act IV. Scene I.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: YES, it was the desire of your Lovers, that you shou'd be acquainted; besides our design requires it.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I find nothing in their desires, but what is very agreeable; and 'tis not without a great deal of joy that I receive so fair an acquaintance: Nothing shall be wanting in me to perfect a friendship, that shall render us dear to each other.

sp.speaker: Zerb.
sp.p: To me the Proposition is most pleasing. But, Signior Negotiator, pray give us an account by what stratagem you drew the Money from the covetous old Fathers of our Lovers?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Yes, and how your wits are employ'd for a supply. Signior Octavio had the hard fortune to be Arrested just then.

sp.speaker: Zerb.
sp.p: Do, I love roguery at my heart;— and you shall find by my countenance, that you don't tell it to one insensible of ingenuity.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: O! here comes Signior Octavio in hast; we have no leisure now.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: The enemy's at hand.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: We'l leave you the Field to deal with him I have instructed; Madam Aurelia, come; whilst they play their Game, I'l entertain you with the relation of what you have a desire to hear; which, I'm sure, will be diversion enough for so short a time.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: This Philosopher was very impertinent and talkative:— I'l now consult.— Ha!— who's this discoursing with Aurelia?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: How, Fair Aurelia! do you speak this in earnest?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: In very good earnest.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Will you Marry, then?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: And to morrow?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Yes, to morrow.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: And can you (Fair, cruel One) abandon me and my vows; and forget all the obliging protestations you have made to me?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I marry, one not for Love, but Money, a thing which I want, and you have not; and you know well enough how the World goes with them that want Money, that must be had whatever it cost. And I take this opportunity to set my heart at ease; my Husband is a man that can't live very long, I warrant you I shall be a Rich Widow in a year or two, and then I shal be able to make you amends for the injury.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Is this the Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Yes, this is the Gentleman that is to be my Husband?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Signior, I wish you much joy of your Marriage, and dedicate my noblest Services to you; I assure you, you wed a Lady of great Beauty, and eminent Perfections: And to you also, Madam, I wish all happiness imaginable; you have made an excellent Choice; He has the mein of a worthy Person, and the looks of one in all things adapted for a good Husband. Signior, I desire your friendship, we'l keep a good correspondence, we'l visit, and see one another daily.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: You do us both so great an honour, we shall always be glad of your good company.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: And I shall be extreme glad to see you and your noble Bridegroom at Court, where I have interest, and can be able to serve you.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I will be often there when I am Married.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Madam, your Creature and Slave. And Signior, your Vassal and Humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Signior Spittzaferro, this young Gentleman is a Courtier, he will do you any service there for my sake: But we'l talk more on't another time. I'm still busy about my affairs. Your Servant, Signior.— To morrow,— to morrow.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p:
To morrow, to morrow; the sound has something in't that is doleful; my mind gives no good prognosticks of this
Marriage; I'l hear the opinion of Signior Scaramouch. Hola! Signior Scaramouch?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: What is your pleasure with me, Signior Spittzaferro?

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Signior Scaramouch, I want your advice in a small concern, and I am come on purpose to be resolv'd in my doubts:— O! this is well; here's one will hearken to a man.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Signior Spittzaferro; pray alter your positive manner of speaking. Our Philosophy teaches us not to speak any decisive Proposition, but to discourse of every thing with uncertainty, to suspend always one judgment. And for this reason you ought not to say, I am come, but— I think I am come;— or,— it seems to me I am come.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Seems to me, or, I think?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Seems to me, it may well seem to me, that I am come, when I am here.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: That is no good consequence; for that may seem, or appear to a man, which in reality is not.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Why, am not I come hither when I am here?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: That's uncertain, we can be sure of nothing, and therefore ought to doubt of every thing.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: What, am not I here, and are not you talking to me?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: It seems to me that you are here, and I think that I am talking to you; but yet I am not certain that it is so.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Euh! what a Devil, don't I know't, and don't you know't well enough, that it not only seems so, or appears so, but that it is certainly so?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Nego, nego, we are sure of nothing; and to convince you that we can have no certain knowledg, let me tell you,— there is nothing in the intellect but what was first in the senses, and by them conveyd to the understanding. Now, our senses being fallible, the knowledg which depend upon them, cannot be infallible, and so not certain: Ergo, Signior, you don't know for certain that you are here.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Pray don't stand upon these niceties, but let us talk of our business. I come to acquaint you that I have thoughts of Marrying.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: That's more than I know.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: I tell you, I have.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: It may be you do.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: The Gentlewoman is very pretty, and very young.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Very likely.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Will it be discreetly done of me to Marry, or not?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: It may, and it may not.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Eh! what canting is this! I ask you, Signior, if I shall do well to marry the Lady I speak of?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: As it happens.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Will it be ill done of me?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Peradventure I, peradventure no.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: For Heaven-sake, Signior, answer me as you shou'd.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: 'Tis my endeavour.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: I have a very great kindness for the Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: That may be.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Her Father and I are agreed.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Perhaps you may.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: But I am only affraid, that if I marry, I shall be a Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: 'Tis not impossible.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: What think you?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Not unlikely.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Shall I, think you?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Such things have been.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: What wou'd you do, were you in my place?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: I can't tell.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: What wou'd you advise me to?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: What you think best.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: But what do you think best?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: What pleases you.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Peu! a Pox!— and is that all?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: I'l have no hand in't.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Let it be as 'twill.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Euh! the Devil! I'l make you change your note, with a Pox to you! you Philosophical Blockhead.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Ah! ah! ah!

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: I am quit with you for your canting, and I'm satisfi'd.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Whence this insolence! how dare you have the audacity to strike a Philosopher!

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: O, pray correct this manner of speaking; you ought to doubt of every thing; you ought not to say I did strike you, but that you think I did strike you; or it seem'd, or appear'd so.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: I'l complain to Justice.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: I'l have no hand in't.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: I'l have satisfaction for the injury.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Peradventure I, peradventure no.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: I have the marks of your blows on my flesh to shew.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: That may be.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: You have made me all o're black and blue.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Not unlikely.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Justice will award me good damage.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: That's more than I know.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: It shall be a dear striking.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Let it be as 'twill.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: You shall hear of me.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Such things have been; Adieu.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Signior Scaramouch, the business is done, a Divorce agreed on, the Parties consenting, my Son disengag'd; and now we may proceed to our designs.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: But I see not Octavio yet: What a murrain made him go a fishing?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: O, poor wretch! O, unfortunate! ah! ah! Poveretto!

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Who's here?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Servitore! Signior Reverendissime, Signior Scientissime, Signior Excellentissime, Signior Illustrissime.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: What's your business?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior, I was an unfortunate Inhabitant of Ligorn, had many losses at Sea; all my effects were seiz'd on by my Creditors; I fled away with this little, to secure something for a future subsistence.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: You wou'd sell it?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signiorsi; I fled hither for refuge, my Creditors have notice of it, and are come after me to lay me in Prison. I wou'd turn it into Money, and go presently a Shipboard, and try my fortune at Sea.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: What, will you take an ounce?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Half a Ducat.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Half a Ducat?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior si.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Half a Ducat?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior si.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Ap— pouh! here's a Fool.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: How many ounces is there in all?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Eight hundred.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: And you'l sell't for 800 Ducats and a half.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior si.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: He's an Ignorant.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Ap— pouh! a Sot.
This is my house, I'l go in and weigh't.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Ap,— ap,— ap,— a.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: He's going to weigh't.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Oh! Servitore!

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: What is your name, Signior?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Trivoline, Merchant of Ligorn.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Did you buy all this Plate your self?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior, no; it was my Father's, old Signior Trivoline's.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: I'l buy it of you for your Father's sake.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: For the sake of old Signior Trivoline, that was Merchant of Ligorn?

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: For the sake of old Signior Trivoline, Merchant of Ligorn.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: I thank you, Signior Pancrace.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Hau!

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: What's the matter, Signior Pancrace?

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Hau! how did you know my name?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: O Diavolo! because you were my Father's Friend.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: You never saw me before.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior, no; but I have often heard my Father, old Signior Trivoline, Merchant of Ligorn, say, that he had but one friend in the World, and that was one, Signior Doctore Pancrace.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: What does he mean? I never heard of any— Signior Trivoline.—
But I'l buy the Plate, and out of the gains re-imburse my self of the Sum I paid for the Divorce. I'l step into the House, and fetch you the Money.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: He! he! he! Oh! here comes Signior Scaramouch.

div.stage: Enter Scaramouch, with the Plate and Money.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: It weighs so much: Heaven sends me this good fortune for redeeming my Son.— Here, take your Money.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: How much?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Four hundred Ducats.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior, no.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: No?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior, no.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: How much then?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Eight hundred Ducats and a half.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Signior si, here's 400 whole Ducats.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior, no; I'l have 800 half Ducats

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Ap— pouch!

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Causa Signior?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Bono! here's 800 half Ducats for you.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Signior Trivoline, here.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior si.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Here.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior si▪

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Here.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior si.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Here.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior si.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: I knew old Signior Trivoline; he was my good Friend.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior si.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Take your Money.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Eh! Signior Scaramouch.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Eh! Signior Pancace.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: I have bought it, Signior Scaramouch.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior si.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: I have bought it, Signior Pancrace.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior si.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: You have sold it to me.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior si.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: No, to me.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior si.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: How's that?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: You'l give me 800 half Ducats?

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Signior si.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: And you'l give me 800 half Ducats?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Signior si.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: It's a bargain.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Here's 800 half Ducats in Gold.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior si, for your part?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: For the Plate.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior, no.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: You'l not give 800 more?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Signior, no.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Not for Signior Pancrace?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Signior, no.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Nor won't you give eight hundred more, Signior Pancrace.

div.stage: Harl. goes towards the door, and turns his face.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Signior, no.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: How wou'd you both buy it then?

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Ah! go to the Devil!

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Servitore!

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Signior Scaramouch, he's a Fool; I'l buy it all as for my self, and you shall be one half in the purchase.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Signior si.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior Pancrace, you won't give 800 more?

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: No, no.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Ah! Bono; you'l not give it for the sake of old Signior Trivoline?

div.stage: Goes neerer the door, and turns.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Ah! Adieu;— you'l not give it?

div.stage: Goes to the door, and turns.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: You'l give no more?

div.stage: Stands sidelong, one half out of the door.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: No, no, no, Signior, no.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Nor you?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Signior, no.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Basta, Signior Pancrace, give me your Money then.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: There 'tis in Gold.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Eight hundred Ducats and a half, just?

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Signior si.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: For the sake of old Signior Trivoline.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Signior si.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Servitore! Signior Pancrace, Adieu.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Ap-pouh! a Fool.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Ah! so, Signior Scaramouch; now let's see our good bargain.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Signior si, ap pouh!

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Then we'l go in, and divide it equally by weight.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Si, ap pouh!

div.stage: Panc. takes the Sack by the end to tumble the Plate out, and nothing but Earthen-ware appears; Scar. takes up a piece, makes faces, and let's it fall.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Oh! Signior Scaramouch, what's here?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Signior?

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Oh! Signior Scaramouch; O! Maleditto; O! Cullio-N●rio; O! Diavolo.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Oh! que cosa— cou— &c.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p:
Eh! What was the meaning of this Blockheadly Philosopher, I cou'd not get a positive word from him.— Oh!— here are Enter Aurelia, Zerbinetta, like Gypsies, singing and dancing. some Gypsies, I'l see what they'l
say to the business; they'r very merry: Heark you there, can you tell my Fortune?

sp.speaker: Zerb.
sp.p: Yes, yes; my fine Sir; here are two can tell you your Fortune.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Come, cross our hands with a piece of Silver, we will tell you something shall be for your good.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Look you;— here are both hands cross'd.

sp.speaker: Zerb.
sp.p: You have a very good Phisiogmony, my fine Sir; a very good Phisiogmony.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Yes, a lucky Phisiogmony; the Phisiogmony of one that shall be something one of these days.

sp.speaker: Zerb.
sp.p: You shall be marri'd e're long, my fine Sir; you shall be marri'd e're long.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: You shall marry a fine Wife, a fine Wife.

sp.speaker: Zerb.
sp.p: Yes, a Wife that every body shall love, and make much of.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: A Wise that shall get you a great many friends, my fine Sir; that shall get you a great many friends.

sp.speaker: Zerb.
sp.p: A Wife that shall make you known and noted at Court.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: A Wife that shall bring a great many Gallants to your House.

sp.speaker: Zerb.
sp.p: A Wife, for whose sake you shall be visited every day.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: A Wife that shall get you a great Reputation.

sp.speaker: Zerb.
sp.p: You shall be esteem'd for her sake, my fine Sir; you shall be esteem'd for her sake.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Oh! very good: But, pray tell me, shall I be in danger to be made a Cuckold?

sp.speaker: Zerb.
sp.p: A Cuckold?

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: A Cuckold?

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Yes, shall I be in danger to be made a Cuckold?

sp.speaker: Zerb. Aur.
sp.p: — La! la! la! la!—

div.stage: Both sing and dance, and Ex.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Why the Devil don't you answer me? I wou'd know if I shall be a Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Zerb.
sp.p: You a Cuckold?

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Yes, I ask if I shall be a Cuckold?

sp.speaker: Zerb. Aur.
sp.p: — La! la! la! la!—

div.stage: Both sing and dance, and Ex.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Signior Spittzaferro, what comfort do they give you?

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: A pox o'the Carrions, they'l have left me unresolv'd too.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: I have heard of a Cunning-man hard by, that is famous for his Art of Astrology and Magick; who, by representations, can shew you what-ever you have a mind to see.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Signior Plautino, let's go find him out, for I'm resolv'd to know my doom.

div.stage: Enter Scaramouch and Harl. with a great Sack, which he places betwixt the Scenes.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Oh! I have trac'd this right; now for my revenge.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Harlequin, where's Octavio?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Your Money was very acceptable; Mr. Pyrat presents his Humble Service to you.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: But where's Octavio?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Oh! he's safe, but you are not.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Eh! why? what?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: There are people hunting all about for you, to kill you.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Me?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior si.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Ah! Who?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: The Gentlewomans Brother that Signior Cynthio has marri'd, believes that the design which you have to make a Match between him and your Daughter, is the main reason why the breaking off of the Marriage is so much endeavour'd; and he's resolv'd to kill you, to be reveng'd. All his acquaintance of Indigent Officers and Bravoes are enquiring after you, to be the death of you; at least half a score have enquir'd of me for you already.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: To kill me?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: They swore they'd be the death of you; but I told 'em you did not care for that.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Not care.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: No; for, said I, Signior Scaramouch is a Philosopher, and is not afraid of death. He cares no more for his Body, than I do for my old Shooes.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: You may bruise his flesh, and break his bones; but you cannot reach his mind: A Philosopher's mind is invulnerable. Did not I say right, Scaramouch?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: O, Harlequin! what must I do, Harlequin?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Oh! Signior Scaramouch; to see a Philosopher! Fear puts me in a fright too, I cannot hold a joint still: stay, I'l look about.
Oh! O!

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Oh! Harlequin! Harlequin!

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: No, no, 'twas nothing.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Canst think of no way to help me?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior, no; heark,— let me look agen:— What's here,— a Sack? Ah! Signior Scaramouch, Fortune is your friend: Put your self into this, and I'l— ha—

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Oh! a!

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: No,— there's no-body; so put your self in, and I'l take you upon my back like a burden, and carry you home.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Si, si.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Hast, hast; I hear somebody come.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: So,— so, Harlequin.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Keep close, stir not, what-ever happens.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: No, Harlequin, no.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Hide, hide, Signior Scaramouch; yonder comes one, keep close.

sp.speaker: Feign'd.
sp.p: Dam this Signior Scaramouch, this Musty Philosopher; if I find him, I'l cut his throat.
— Signior Scaramouch is not one that desires to have his throat cut; he's a very civil Person, a Scholar, and a Philosopher.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: A Philosopher! a Fool, a Dog, a Rogue, a Rascal, a Son of a Whore.
— He's wa orthy Philosopher.— Keep close.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Is he a friend of yours?
— Signior si.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: I am glad I have met with a Friend of his, by whom I may present my most profound Respects to him; which I will do in this most hearty manner.
sp.stage: Runs crying round the Sack, and beats him.
sp.p: — Hold, hold, hold.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: I'l dodg you Sirrah; do you dodg? I shall meet with you▪
— Ah! ah! ah! Hold, hold, hold; ah! ah!

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: My service to him, my love and service. Adieu, my good Friend, to Signior Scaramouch.
— Oh! Signior Scaramouch!

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: I can endure no longer.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: O! I am bruised. I am beaten.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: How's that? I was beaten.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior, no.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Signior si.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: O yes, yes, Signior; as I ran round the Sack to save my self, the blows sometimes light upon you.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: You shou'd a run somewhere else.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: I'l look and see if the Coast be clear.— Oh! have a care,— have a care; I see one with a great pair of Whiskers, and a Cap lin'd with Fur.— Close,— close.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Gooden morgen Lans-man, gooden morgen; were sal ick vind'n, Myn-heir, vander Scaramouch.
— Vander Scaramouch?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Yaw, Myn-heir, yaw, yaw.
— Yaw, Myn-heir, yaw, yaw.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Were sal ick vind'n hem
— Find him.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Ken uwe no Duytch spreken? wil ghy neit spreken?
— Spreken,— spreken,— spreken.—

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Ghy Sacraments a Hounts-foot, ick sal uwe lustick slagen.
— Ah! ah! ah!

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Ten hundred Duysant Devils,— mock uwe zeil Haulen Hountsfoot.
— Ah! ah! ah!

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Ghy Sacraments a— ick sal vind'n Myn▪ heir vander Scaramouch;— ick sal hem slagen,— Ghy Sacraments, a— ten hundred 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 Devils
— Oh! the Devil wander him, and slopen him; and ten hundred thousand Devils go with him.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: O, my ribs!

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: O, my shoulders!

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: O! Signior Scaramouch, I was not neer you.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: I felt every blow as perfectly as before.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior, no.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Signior si.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: You did but hear 'em.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: I felt 'em.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior, no, fear made you think so.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: I feel 'em still.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior si, by sympathy, sympathy.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Sympathy; O, Diavolo! sympathy!

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: O, Signior; here are some roaring Boys come singing along, and every one a Bottle o' Wine ins hand. Lye still till they are pass'd.

div.stage: He acts three men, in speaking and singing in three several Voices.

sp.p: Well, now let's go find out Scaramouch.
And drink and sing all the way.
Let's sing 'tother catch, and make an end of our Bottle first.
I'l begin.

p.hi: Chi non beve, vita breve, gaudera.
I'l bon Vino, che ' divino, viver fa.

sp.p: Confusion to Signior Scaramouch.— So.
Chi non beve, &c.
Confusion to Scaramouch.
Chi non beve, &c.
Come, here's one shall drink and sing too.
Eh! Signior; I am in hast.
Sing, sirrah.
I can't sing.
Sing after me.— Chi non beve.
Chi non beve.
Fie, fie; sing after me, and observe how I beat time upon the Sack.— Chi non beve.
Chi non beve.
Agen,— agen;— Chi non beve, &c.
Chi non beve.
He's a Blockhead, let's leave him, and go find out Scaramouch.
Let's take this Rogue with us to shew us the way.
Ay, ay;— let's take him with us.
I do'nt know him.
You lye, you dog!— along, shew us the way.
Signior, no; I have business.
You won't go then?
No.
Let's beat him till he will.

div.stage: Sear. peeps out of the Sack.

sp.p: Knock his brains out.
Lay him on soundly.
Aye, soundly.
as all 3. Soundly, soundly, soundly.

div.stage: As Harl. acts this, Scaramouch lets fall the Sack, comes softly out, and stands just behind him, with his Girdle ready to beat him, as he turns.— Harl. turns to beat the Sack, sees Scaramouch, runs off; who follows▪ beating him.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Aye, soundly, soundly, soundly.

div.trailer: The End of the fourth Act.

div.head: Act V. Scene I.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: I'M not acquainted with him; but I have heard great commendation of his skill: 'Tis somewhere hereabout he lives: Look you where he comes forth.

div.stage: Enter Harlequin like a Magician, with a great pair of Spectacles on his Nose, a long Prospective-glass, looking at Spittzaferro at a distance.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: A man of a bold Aspect, fortunate Phisiognomy, sanguine Complexion, strong Constitution, great Appetite, and good Digestion; but by nature timerous and diffident; therefore sleeps not sound.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Exactly you.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Aged 53 years, 2 Months, 9 days, 37 hours, three hundred threescore and three minutes and a half.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: What says he?

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: He's telling you how old you are, a new way of counting these learn'd Men have got. See, he's coming towards you.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Signior, I'm your Servant.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: You are not, I pay you no Wages.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: I give you a good-morrow.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: You give me nothing.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: There is some Gold.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: A good gift is a good-morrow.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: I come, Signior, to kiss your hands.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: There.

div.stage: Hits him in the Chops first with one hand▪ and then with the other.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Euh! what's the meaning?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: And there.— How you have done what you come for?

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: I perceive he's not a Man of Ceremony.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: You are a Man of great vulgarity, Signior; you ought to make your Approaches in a more peculiar manner, and not to disgorge such vulgar Phrases in the face of the Learn'd.

sp.speaker: ‛ Plaut.
sp.p: Pray ben't so critical; we are not us'd to treat with persons of your profound Science.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: In short▪ Signior, my Name is—

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Spittzaferro.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: I am come to tell you that I am about—

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: To Marry.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Signior si, and desire to know of you—

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: If you may do't with safety.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Signior si, and if I shall not be—

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: A Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: He knows all before you tell it him.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: O, impertinence!▪ tell a Magician what you come for! Whiz!— whose Art is knowledg it self. Buz! who reads what's written in the Stars. Fitz! who holds intelligence with Spirits. Ptru— ru— ru!— to whose eyes the Book of Fate lies open.— Bro,— thro,— ro,— ro,— rou!

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Most learn'd Sir; you have sufficiently inform'd his understanding, as to his conversation; now be pleas'd to satisfy his curiosity, which brought him hither: and by your Magick representations shew him something that may be to his advantage.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Basta, basta, Signior, basta. Follow me in.

div.stage: Enter agen in a Room. Harl. with a dark Lanthorn.

lg.l: Tricola, tracola, whiz! Tricola, tracola, Buz!
Tricola, tracola, Fitz!
Tricola, tracola, Ptru-ru-ru!
Tricola, tracola, Bro-thro-rou!
Tricola, tracola. Goes about prancing, sings this ridiculously; at last stops.
Tricola, tracola.
Tricola, tracola.
Doodle doodle-doo.
My Conjurations are Pacifick; A vision of horns appears in shadows, increase to a vast bigness, and vanish.
Your Fortune see in Hierogliphick.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: See, Signior Spittzaferro.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: This vision's no good omen.

div.stage: A vision of horns appears, increases and decreases in bigness several times, at last vanish upward.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Tricola, tracola; tricola, tracola; tricola, tracola, &c. Toodle-doodle-doo, &c.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Mind, Sir, mind.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: Cucko.

div.stage: A Cucko appears in shadow, cries 3 times, and each time grows bigger, at last, flies up out o▪ sight.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Heark.

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: Cucko.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Say you so?

sp.speaker: Bird.
sp.p: Cucko.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: This Bird gives no good Augury of my Marriage.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: I'm affraid 'twill be something unfortunate.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Tricola, tracola; tricola, tracola; tricola, tracola, &c. Toodle-doodle-doodle-doodle-doo.

div.stage: Men appear in shadows with horns on their heads, grow bigger and less several times, several times appear and disappear, at last dance with a great pair of horns in each hand; they offer as it were to Spittzaferro, shaking 'em at him with each hand, shaking their heads, then jump up out o'sight one after another.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Signior Plautino, these were Cuckolds, they shook their heads at me; that's no good sign.

sp.speaker: ‛ Plaut.
sp.p: We'l know what it signifies. Signior, what's the meaning of all this?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Tricola, tracola; tricola, tracola; tri—

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: What are you going to do now?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: To Conjure up the Devil himself in person, who shall tell you the meaning on't. Tricola, tracola; tricola, tracola, &c.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: The Devil himself. Euh! Servitore, Signior, tricola, Servitore.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Euh! Euh! Signior.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: No, no, Servitore.
Eh! eh! he! tricola, tracola, &c.

div.stage: Enter Spittzaferro and Plautino in the Street.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Signior Spittzaferro, what think you How?

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Signior Plautino, I think 'tis better to be a Man than a Beast; and since Heaven has created me one, I'le take care not to be metamorphis'd by a Woman.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Signior Spittzaferro, here is Signior Alberto your Brother-in-Law; Signior Alberto, this is the worthy person that is to marry your Sister.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: Signior I am just now luckily arriv'd; my Father has told me the good news▪ I'm glad Aurelia has the good fortune to have a man of your Character for her Husband. I shall be proud of such a Brother-in-Law.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Signior I kiss your hands.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: Time won't allow farther Ceremony; my Father sent me to tell you, that they want your company. Come Sir, I'le wait on you.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Excuse me Signior Alberto.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: No Ceremony, I pray.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: No haste, no haste.

sp.speaker: Cynth.
sp.p: The Scrivener is there, the Writings are ready, they want you to set your Hand and Seal to the Jointure you make my Sister.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: No question.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: Come Sir, let's go.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: I have a word to say to you first.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: To me?

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Signior si.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: What I pray?

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: I'le go before, and tell 'em you are coming.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Signior Alberto, 'tis true, I ask'd your Fathers consent to marry Aurelia; he was very inclinable; but upon more deliberate consideration I find, I am a little too far in years for her, and I am convinc'd I shall not be a fit Husband for her.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p:
Excuse me, my Sister thinks very well of you, and I
doubt not but she'l be happy in you.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: No, she won't; I have sometimes strange melancholy Fits, and whilst they last, I am very extravagant; and I'm sure 'twill be too much for her to bear with me in those humours.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: My Sister is of a very good disposition, and as merry, she'l sing and laugh, and play a thousand tricks to divert you; she'l be the fittest Wife alive for you.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Then Signior I have some infirmities of Body too, which will disgust her.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: That's nothing Signior, a vertuous Wife is never disgusted with her Husband.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: In short Signior, give me leave to tell you, I wou'd not have your Father by any means to let me marry her.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: O Signior, my Father was always a punctual man, and do you think upon his death-bed he'l be worse than his word!

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Tell him Signior, I dispence with his promise, and I—

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: For never so much, he has said it, and you shall have her, let what will be the matter.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Ah! what ado's here!

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: See then Signior Spittzaferro, what a particular esteem and liking my Father has for you; he told the company that the thoughts of this day revived him, and said, if a Duke shou'd now demand my Sister, he shou'd go without her for your sake.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Signior Alberto, I'm extreamly obliged to your Father, for the honour he does me, but I assure you, I am resolv'd not to marry.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: Your reason?

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: The reason is, because marriage is inconvenient for me; Ile imitate my Father and all my Ancestors, who could never be perswaded to marry.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: Nay, nay Signior, you have your liberty, no body as I know will force you against your inclinations. But since tis so, pray go and acquaint my Father with it your self; I have done my message, and am engaged to go another way. Do ye hear Signior, you need not doubt your release; he's one won't impose her on you. Adieu.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Well, Ile go and put an end to this business, that my mind may be free from fears and my 〈◊〉 continue sound.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Signior Pancrace, we are abused, disgraced.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Couzened and cheated.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: That Rogue Harlequin.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: That Rascal Plautino.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: That Villain Harlequin.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: That cursed Plautino, and Knave Harlequin, his wicked Accomplice.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: They shall account for their Rogueries.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: They shall be made Examples, Signior Scaramouch. Let's join in our Revenge.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: We'l have recourse to Justice.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Get Officers and search 'em out.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: We'l have 'em strapado'd▪

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: And sent to the Galleys.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Cherto, Seguro.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Then we'l take a course in order to my Son, whom I will yet have to marry your Daughter Andramo.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Patientia Signior Pancracio, I have receiv'd Letters.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: What from Lauretto, which inform you that your Daughter and mine resolve to be Nuns.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: I have Letters to that effect too, but I'l not consent to't.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Your Son being engaged I am content.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Signior Scaramouch, I will yet recover all.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Matters are gone too far, he loves another.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: I'l make him love agen.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Affection cannot be forced.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: He shall marry her.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: My Daughter shall continue there.
Suspend your Resolutions till we know more of the concern, we'l search 'em out, and have them face to face.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: My Son.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: And mine.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: And Harlequin.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: And Plautino.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: And that Gipsie Baggage shall have no cause to laugh.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Let's about it.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Instantly.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: I now presently, along! Signior Scaramouch.

sp.speaker: Spitz.
sp.p: I found Signior Beronimo more reasonable than I expected; but I believe he thought my refusal an affront, and might slight it out of Pride, but I took him at his word; and now, stand disengag'd Signior, Ieronimo Servitore, Signiora Aurelia, I kiss your hands,— so 'tis well.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Signior Spitzaferro, I'm your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Spit.
sp.p: Signior I am yours.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: My Friend Signior Alberto tells me, you are not a man o'your word.

sp.speaker: Spit.
sp.p: 'Tis confest; but 'tis not without much regret, and—

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: O Signior, no harm at all.

sp.speaker: Spit.
sp.p: I am very much troubled, and wish with all my heart,—

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: No harm done.

sp.speaker: Spit.
sp.p: I should have been very glad that—

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: It matters not Signior, rest contented. Signior be pleased to make choice of one of these two Swords, and take which you like best.

sp.speaker: Spit.
sp.p: One o'these Swords.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Yes, which you please.

sp.speaker: Spit.
sp.p: To what intent?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: After your refusing to marry a Lady, to which you had given your word, I doubt not but you'l take in good part the Complement I come to make you.

sp.speaker: Spit.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: There's a little Billet which Signior Alberto desir'd the favour of me to deliver into your hands.

div.stage:
(Spit. reads)
Signior Spitzaferro, I consider that your refusal to marry my Sister, is an affront to our Family, I demand the
satisfaction of a Gentleman; make choice of your Weapon, and appoint the place and time.
Your Friend and Servant, Alberto.

sp.speaker: Spit.
sp.p: Friend and Servant! What a Complement is there to such a Message?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Other men would make a noise and a buslle, and grow enrag'd against you; but Signior Alberto is a civil person, and one that does things very obligingly, he sends courteously to you, to tell you, that if you please you two will civilly cut one anothers throats.

sp.speaker: Spit.
sp.p: A fine Complement, a very civil person indeed.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Come Signior, chuse your Sword I pray.

sp.speaker: Spit.
sp.p: I kiss your hands Signior, I have ne're a throat to cut; What a Civility's there?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: It must be so if you please.

sp.speaker: Spit.
sp.p: Signior no matter for Complements among Friends, Servitore.

div.stage: Is going off, Octavio pulls him back.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Signior, if you please you must not depart yet; come take which you like best, I'm a little in haste, or I'd allow you more time to make your choice.

sp.speaker: Spit.
sp.p: I have nothing to say to the business.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: You are not pleas'd then to fight him.

sp.speaker: Spit.
sp.p: No, not at all.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: You don't think good to kill one another.

sp.speaker: Spit.
sp.p: Signior no.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: 'Tis against your inclination?

sp.speaker: Spit.
sp.p: Signior si.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: You have made a resolution to the contrary.

sp.speaker: Spit.
sp.p: And please you.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: At least Signior Spitzaferro you'l have no reason to complain, you see I observe method, and do things in order; you go from your word, the party injur'd sends you a Challenge, I bring it, you refuse to fight, I beat you for not accepting the message, that follows of consequence, all this is in course, and I know you are too worthy a person not to approve of proceedings which are so orderly and exact.

sp.speaker: Spit.
sp.p: What a sort of man's this?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Come Signior, chuse your weapon without more ado.

sp.speaker: Spit.
sp.p: Yet agen!

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Signior, I force no body, but you must take it; nor does Signior Alberto compel you to any thing, but you must sight him, if you please.

sp.speaker: Spit.
sp.p: I shall do neither.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: No?

sp.speaker: Spit.
sp.p: Signior, no.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: With your permission then.

sp.speaker: Spit.
sp.p: Ah, ah, ah, ah.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Signior, I have all the reluctancy imaginable to treat you so contrary to all my inclinations; but with your good liking, if you please, I can't forbear till you do me the favour to grant what I request of you.

sp.speaker: Spit.
sp.p: I kiss your hands Signior, give me which you please.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: No Signior, which you please, So, is it not best to do things thus freely and courteously. I'm very glad to find you so inclinable, for you are a very civil person, and one for whom I have a particular respect; I was extream sorry to see you wou'd force me against my Nature. Well Signior, I'l go and acquaint Signior Alberto, that you will please to do him the obligation to meet him at six to morrow morning upon the Mole, with your Sword in your hand, like a gallant person▪ So Signior Spitzaferro I kiss your hands; Your most humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Eh! What a sort of Ceremony, what kind of Complements are these? What an obliging, disobliging person was this? Euh— Malleditto.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Take courage, you see me in the same ill circumstances, and expos'd to the like misfortunes.

sp.speaker: Zerb.
sp.p: You know your birth, and who you are; you have Relations that will reconcile all. But I'm in a condition that that will not appease the anger of a Father, to whom Merit signifies little, and who regards nothing but Wealth.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: O are you caught at last, are your intrigues discover'd? Will you now at last consent to quit your fine choice.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: O Signior, I humbly beg of you, no more to think of separating me from this fair person; I'm hers by a thousand Vows, and by holy Contract she's mine.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: She's a person of such virtue and merit, that when you know her better, you'l have the greatest esteem for her imaginable.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Esteem one that has seduced my Son from his obedience.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: In the hands of Justice!

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: No, I have no esteem for a Vagabond, one of a Race unknown.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Signior Pancracio. regret not that your Son loves a person unknown, one without a portion, and whose quality you are ignorant of; the person from whom he purchas'd her declar'd, passing through a little Village not far from this City, call'd Pitrola, in a time when several Houses were on fire, they found her brought forth into the street, then but an Infant, lying in a Cradle, and left unattended, in the time of this distraction they stole her away.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: What said you?

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: They believ'd it not the Daughter of a Peasant, but a Nurse-Child, having several rich Medals about her Neck, of which they left this one as the most remarkable.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Let me see't.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: By publishing this Story, she may come to the knowledg of her Parents; and this may serve for a circumstance to consirm 'em she is their Daughter.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: O, fortunate discovery! happy confirmation!

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: What say you▪ Signior Scaramouch?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: 'Tis my Daughter whom I lost in the same manner as you speak of.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Your Daughter, Signior Scaramouch?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Yes▪ I own her.

sp.speaker: Zerb.
sp.p: O happy Zerbinetta!

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: No, no, your name is Olivia.
My Sister! unexpected joy.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Signior Pancracio, you have now no longer reason to repent your Son's actions.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Nor you, Signior Scaramouch, have no reason to be angry with your Son, for his love to the fair Aurelia.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: My Son love one that's contracted to another.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Signior Spittzaferro, by the consent of parties, has quitted his pretensions, and I have acquainted Signior Ieronimo with Signior Octavio's love to his Daughter, and he now approves well of it, and resolves nothing shall be wanting in him to gain your approbation of the match.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Signior Plautino, I am content.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Blest agreement!

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Lucky hour!

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: Fortunate Plautino!

sp.speaker: Zerb.
sp.p: Happy conclusion!

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: This good news, I hope makes my Peace with all.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Servitore, Signior Plautino.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: I forgive all but Harlequin; that's a Rogue shan't escape punishment.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: I'l step into Signior Ieronimo, and tell him the good news.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: O! Signior, Servitore; I received your invitation, and take it for a very great favour, that you think me worthy of the honour of your Sword.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: How's this?

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: But, Signior Alberto, let me tell you, that at present I am not in a condition to fight; I will satisfy you in what-ever else shall be requisite.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Aberto! what means he?

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Imagin then that you see me in the Field with my Sword in my hand, sighting against you. Imagin likewise that you have laid me on the ground; publish it thro'out the City, I'l acknowledg it; for the present I do consess my self o'recome. And without any sighting at all, I ask my life of you.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: You have it.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Not that I am affraid to fight, but that it will not be discretion in me at this time.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: As you please.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: And that wisdom tells, 'tis better to do it now, than to submit to your mercy after you have kill'd me.

sp.speaker: bynt.
sp.p: Very true.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Yet, upon condition that you will hereafter demand your life of me, when it shall be inconvenient for you to fight, and I shall send you the like courteous invitation.

sp.speaker: Scarr.
sp.p: What means this?

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Signior Spittzaferro, who do you talk to?

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: To Signior Alberto.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: To Cynthio.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Brother to Signiora Aurelia.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: My Son.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: 'Tis true, Signior Spittzaferro; this Gentleman is not Signior Alberto, but Signior Cynthio; not her Brother, but my Friend, to serve me in my Amour. I was your Rival, and your true Enemy; But now you have quitted your pretensions, and matters are concluded, I'm your Friend hence▪ forward.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Then it will not concern me hereafter to require him to demand his life of me.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: You may sleep in peace.

sp.speaker: Spitt.
sp.p: Ah! Bono, Servitore.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: Signior Scaramouch, Signior Ieronimo is extremely rejoyc'd at the happy conclusion.

div.stage: Enter an Officer bringing in Harlequin in his Magicians habit.

sp.speaker: Offic.
sp.p: Come along, come.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Oh! is he catch'd? he shall have the Strapada.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior si, I deserve it for counterfeiting a Bravo, and cheating you of 206 Pistols.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Ah! Furbo! Villain!

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: And for not being a Philosopher of your Sect, Signior; for not learning Logick, Morals, Physick and Metaphysicks, Signior si.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: He shall be sent to the Galleys for seven years.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p:
Signior si, for not being a Novice, and learning Patience.
Temperance, Sobriety, and not going to a Wench.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Signior Pancrace, his sentence shall be for his whole life.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior si, for telling you your Son went a fishing, and for getting 500 Dollers of you against your will.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Signior Scaramouch, he shall be hang'd out right.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior si, for being a Merchant of Ligorn, and cosening Signior Pancrace and Signior Scaramouch of 800 half Ducats, and for being the Son of old Signior Trivoline.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: He shall be broken alive upon the Wheel.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior si, for having the insolence to put a learned Philosopher into a Sack.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Bestia!

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: For laying him on with a great Cudgel.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Bruto!

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: And beating him till he was all o're black and blue.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: O che Diavolo! Impertinente!

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Away with him to a Magistrate, he shall have his reward for all.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior Officer, I have dropt a Purse of Gold where I stand; take the light and look for't, it belongs to Signior Scaramouch, and Signior Pancrace.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Ah! Bono.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Look for't, Signior Scaramouch, you and I will hold him in the mean time.

div.stage: The Officer holds the Torch to Harlequin's feet to look for't, he treads it out.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Eh! Bestia!

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Excusa, Signior, 'twas by chance.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Go, light it agen, and look for the Money; we'l hold him.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Signior si.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Eh.

div.stage: Harlequin slips out of the Gown as they hold him by the Arms, goes behind them, and hits each two or three times o're the head,— they strike at him, and buffet one another.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Eh.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Bruto!

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Bestia!

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Bruto!

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Bestia.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Ha! ha! he!

div.stage: Enter Officer with a light; looks, and sees them holding the Gown and Cap upon't, and no-body in't.

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Oh! Signior Scaramouch, here's no-body.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: No▪ body?

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: The Villain's escap'd.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: O che Furbo.

sp.speaker: Aur. Zerb.
sp.p: Gone!

sp.speaker: Oct. Cynt.
sp.p: Hah che Cullione!

sp.speaker: Panc.
sp.p: Signior Scaramouch, rest content at present. Now let us go in, have the Musick, eat a good Supper, and make a night on't.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Signior si▪ signior si.

sp.speaker: Plaut.
sp.p: You must all joyn to make a reconciliation for Harlequin. He must for all this come in for the leg of a good Capon.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Signior si, Signior si.

sp.speaker: Oct. Cynt.
sp.p: Come, come, Harlequin's come.

sp.speaker: Aur. Zerb.
sp.p: Aye, come, poor Harlequin.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Servitore, Signior Octavio; Signior Cynthio, Servitore; Signiora Aurelia, Servitore; Servitore Signiora, & Servitore Tutti quanti.

lg.l: THose that were Iudges forty years ago,
Would nothing but strict Comedy allow,
And humours drawn exactly to the life.
The Poet here, with nature is at strife.
We show'd to day only what's strange and new,
Where tho the Picture was not drawn so true,
Yet th'oddness of the piece may pleasure give,
As that alone makes the Dutch painting thrive.
We in this age, which is so much for change,
Have leapt the Hedg, and now with freedom range.
What's naturally witty will not do,
Unless there's something yet more strange than you.
If like your selves an airy Fop we show,
You cry, Dam-me Jack, that was stole from you.
No humor on the Stage will pass for Wit,
Cause ev'ry day you act your selves i'the Pit.
In Coffee-House but half the Fool y'expose,
With talk impertinent, and silly Oaths,
The Mall the Fop at full proportion shows.
To have you here then were dull Repetition,
'Twould be at least the fourth and worst Edition.
Nor can we now any new humor meet,
In all Cheap-side, Cornhill, and Lumbard-street,
Upon the change, they're formal, dull, precise,
Of Dutch and French most gravely telling Lies;
Foretelling the success of Foreign War,
What may portend the Whale and Blazing-Star.
Since they're so gravely dull, aud you so light,
Our Play we hope may've done you both some right.
Even in this Play will be some natural touches,
Whilst you're such Harlequins, they Scaramouches.
